CHARLES ISHERWOOD    + 'LAUGH WHORE' For indisputable evidence that comedy is fueled by anger, take a gander at Mario Cantone's face as he approaches a payoff line in ''Laugh Whore,'' his gussied-up stand-up-comedy show. The dancing eyebrows flatline. The jaw settles into a strained grimace. The soft brown eyes are transformed into bottomless pools of hostility. Mr. Cantone is in fact most appealing, and most hilarious, when he's seething his way through a tale of irritation, the voice spiraling suddenly from a friendly hum to a train whistle. Probably best known as one of the gay accessories sported by the ''Sex and the City'' gals to match their Manolos, Mr. Cantone is himself gay. Much of the funniest material in ''Laugh Whore'' is an expression of a buoyantly, exuberantly, even belligerently gay sensibility. The director Joe Mantello oversees this production, but much of it retains the formless feeling of a club routine. Structure and thematic design, not necessities in an hourlong club set, are more important for a two-hour, two-act Broadway engagement, and they are missing in action here. But if ''Laugh Whore'' may not prove to be the shapeliest of the many solo shows heading to a Broadway theater near you this fall, it is certainly a fine first salvo (2:15). Cort, 138 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $81.25.  ISHERWOOD    + ' 'NIGHT, MOTHER' As your grandmother or therapist probably told you, there is something to be said for staying busy in a time of crisis. Playing a pair of women whose shared life is about to be torn asunder, Edie Falco and Brenda Blethyn have an ocean of household chores to swim through in the strangely uninvolving revival of Marsha Norman's '' 'Night, Mother,'' directed by Michael Mayer. Putting candy in jars, cleaning out the refrigerator, bagging garbage, folding towels, making cocoa: such tasks are sometimes enough even to eclipse the harsh awareness of Thelma Cates (Ms. Blethyn) that her daughter, Jessie (Ms. Falco), has announced that she will be killing herself in a couple of hours. On the other hand, all that domestic industry only rarely disguises our suspicion that these two first-rate actresses are never quite at home in their roles. Or the uneasy realization that Ms. Norman's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama is looking more artificial than it did 20 years ago (1:30). Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $66.25 to $86.25.  BRANTLEY    *++ 'RECKLESS' The most dangerous smile on Broadway fills the opening moments of this animated revival of Craig Lucas's comedy from 1988, directed by Mark Brokaw. The smile belongs to Mary-Louise Parker, playing an improbably ecstatic housewife on Christmas Eve, and it's enough to make anyone grin back at her. In the course of the show, however, Ms. Parker's smile wavers, tightens and shrinks in ways that seem to age her at least a decade, so that by the end you may feel as if you've undergone high-speed Prozac withdrawal. ''Reckless'' milks the tension between a goofy surface intoxication and a core of cold sobriety. The story of a runaway waif-woman in a violent world, ''Reckless'' remains a beguiling, sneaky crash course in the loss of innocence. Granted, it's as thick with whimsy as Pee-wee Herman's playhouse, and its ideal environment is not a big Broadway theater. But Ms. Parker's high incandescence and emotional fluidity go some distance in justifying this scaled-up production (1:45). Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $51 to $79; $26 student rush tickets available the day of the show.  BRANTLEY    *+ 'TWELVE ANGRY MEN' This stage adaptation of Reginald Rose's celebrated television drama from 1954 (made into a film in 1957) suggests that sometimes the best way to present a fossil is just to polish it up and put it on display without disguise, annotation or apology. As a tidy portrait of clashing social attitudes in a jury room, it definitely creaks with age. But somehow the creaks begin to sound like soothing music, a siren song from a period of American drama when personalities were drawn in clean lines, the moral was unmistakable and the elements of a plot clicked together like a jigsaw puzzle without a single missing piece. Even those who like their theater hip and cerebral might want to lower their eyebrows for this 90-minute production, directed with brisk straightforwardness by Scott Ellis. With an ensemble that includes Boyd Gaines, Philip Bosco, Mark Blum and Peter Friedman, this is a showcase for some of New York's finest character actors, all of whom manage to chew the scenery without smacking their lips (1:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $46.25 to $86.25.  BRANTLEY    + 'WHOOPI' Whoopi Goldberg has been working in Hollywood for two decades now. Presumably she's met a lot of directors out there. But scan the program for Ms. Goldberg's solo show, which has returned to the Lyceum Theater on Broadway for a 20th-anniversary engagement, and you'll find none listed. The movie star and television personality has chosen to dispense with one in remounting her collection of monologues, just as she did when this career-igniting show made its debut on Broadway. Twenty years ago, the omission could be forgiven as the boundless confidence of a bright young talent. At 49, Ms. Goldberg is now an established performer, and the oversight looks more like folly. Ms. Goldberg remains an engaging presence, but this sluggish show desperately needs a stringent theatrical intelligence. Ms. Goldberg's most ardent fans may be happy to make the acquaintance of the half-dozen different characters she portrays here. But even the funniest monologues would benefit from judicious editing. ''Whoopi'' is still good company, to be sure. And yet, as anyone who has observed her eclectic career knows, she is perhaps not always the best judge of material. ''Whoopi'' offers further evidence that, innately incandescent though she may be, Ms. Goldberg's gifts shine brightest when they are strictly harnessed (1:30). Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Wednesdays at 8 p.m. Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 7 and 10 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $26.25 to $76.25.  ISHERWOOD    Off Broadway    'BELLE ÉPOQUE' The époque doesn't seem so very belle in Martha Clarke and Charles L. Mee's ambitious attempt to distill onstage the seedy, absinthe-tinted glamour that Toulouse-Lautrec captured in oils and pastels in late 19th-century Paris. As in their prior collaboration, ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' the authors seek to strip away the sentimental varnish that has congealed around popular depictions of the milieu they are exploring. Ms. Clarke and Mr. Mee are intrigued by the gloom beneath the gaiety. ''Belle Époque'' focuses on the painter who immortalized the denizens of Montmartre in his art. Mark Povinelli, an actor whose small stature belies a sizable force, plays Toulouse-Lautrec. He is surrounded by an eccentric array of performers who plied their trade in the clubs of Montmartre. With the aid of Jane Greenwood's plush, gorgeously detailed costumes and Christopher Akerlind's invigorating lighting, the production casts a seductive visual spell. And Ms. Clarke's staging has a bustling freedom that is a fine theatrical metaphor for the restless speed of Toulouse-Lautrec's acute eye, forever settling on unexpected moments and awkward poses. But the musical and visual enticements of ''Belle Époque'' are encumbered by Mr. Mee's text, which often strikes an arch, discordant note (1:25). Mitzi E. Newhouse, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m; Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $70.  ISHERWOOD    'THE FOREIGNER' The Cinderella schlemiel has clearly become Matthew Broderick's most trusted onstage alter-ego. Having buffed this persona to a high sheen as the inhibited accountant Leopold Bloom in the hit Broadway musical ''The Producers,'' Mr. Broderick brings his sad-sack slouch and adenoidal uneasiness to ''The Foreigner,'' Larry Shue's deliberately doltish comedy of improbabilities from the mid-1980's. There's no denying that Mr. Broderick, who plays a gray-souled British proofreader on vacation in rural Georgia, has this persona as securely nailed down as any performer since (he should pardon the comparison) Jerry Lewis. The production allows Mr. Broderick a few joyous interludes of precisely rendered, raging goofiness. But despite a top-drawer supporting cast, which includes Frances Sternhagen and Kevin Cahoon, what's between the bright comic riffs brings to mind the sort of contrived television sitcom that you wind up watching, passively and masochistically, when you're too depressed to change the channel (2:45). Roundabout Theater Company at the Pels Theater, Steinberg Center, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 7:30 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 7:30 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $61.25 to $71.25.  BRANTLEY    * 'THE GOD OF HELL' Sam Shepard's robust new farce, which he has described as ''a takeoff on Republican fascism,'' is neither a smooth nor subtle play. But at its best it has a punch-drunk paranoia that brings to mind Mr. Shepard's salad days as the ultimate wild young dramatist of several decades ago. Directed by Lou Jacob, this 90-minute portrait of an old-time America invaded by a cruel new breed of Americans starts off much more satisfyingly than it finishes. And what it has to say about a nation forced to march in regimental lockstep is pretty standard agitprop. But unlike, say, the more literal-minded ''Embedded,'' Tim Robbins's satire about the invasion of Iraq, ''The God of Hell'' pokes fun at its own righteous self as well as its broad political targets. The show's top-of-the-line cast is led by Randy Quaid and J. Smith-Cameron, who are priceless as a politically naïve farming couple in rural Wisconsin (1:20). Actors Studio Drama School Theater, 151 Bank Street, (212) 279-4200. Mondays, Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $60.  BRANTLEY    * 'NINE PARTS OF DESIRE' The voices are a study in contrasts: vivid and subdued, sophisticated and naïve, seductive and standoffish. But they cohere to form a powerful collective portrait of suffering and endurance in Heather Raffo's impassioned theatrical documentary about the lives of contemporary Iraqi women. A solo piece written and performed by Ms. Raffo, an actress of Iraqi and American heritage, the play is a welcome reminder that the costs of tyranny and violent conflict are borne not by some amorphous, insentient collective population but by individuals, in this case women whose lives have been frayed and fractured, sometimes beyond repair, by the tortured history of their country. Bush foes expecting a polemical broadside will be disappointed. Ms. Raffo drew on more than 10 years of interviews to assemble her theatrical mosaic, and the commendable results reveal that she is a journalist, not a purveyor of propaganda. There is plenty here to fuel outrage at the suffering of Iraqi citizens directly caused by American bombing. But Ms. Raffo's women also bear witness to the monstrousness of Saddam Hussein's regime, with more than one of the play's characters fiercely avowing that no price is too high to pay for ridding the country of his brutality (1:30). Manhattan Ensemble Theater, 55 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 925-1900. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $60.  ISHERWOOD    * 'RODNEY'S WIFE' Seemingly light conversation scrapes the skins of the characters in Richard Nelson's sharply etched study of dislocation, loneliness and sexual betrayal, directed by the playwright and and starring David Strathairn as a fading American movie star working in Rome. And you are always aware of the strain and snappishness that arises when people politely avoid saying what is on everyone's mind. Long before the unspoken is brought out for airing, Mr. Nelson and his fine cast have created a full emotional geography of a family, replete with deserts and bogs and patches of quicksand. Though the play, which traces the conflicts among the women in the life of Mr. Strathairn's alcoholic character, is centered on what movie ads used to call an ''illicit passion,'' there is nothing prurient about this production. What it offers instead is a deep and sorrowful understanding of how much loneliness there often is in lust. The excellent cast includes Maryann Plunkett, Jessica Chastain and, in a shrewdly mannered performance in the title role, Havilland Morris (1:45). Playwrights Horizons Mainstage Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, (212) 279-4200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2:30 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $55.  BRANTLEY    'A SECOND HAND MEMORY' Woody Allen's unrelentingly glum new play at the Atlantic Theater Company is a drama about two generations of defeated dreamers in 1950's Brooklyn. As the play opens, Eddie Wolfe (Nicky Katt) has been called home from Hollywood to help turn around the family jewelry business, for which he never had much affection. Eddie has an unwanted new wife and a baby on the way, but his permanently darkened brow telegraphs despair and a burning desire to escape. Snapshots from the past reveal layers of guilt, dissatisfaction and recrimination in the family history. Emotional entrapment, and the desperation it causes, have become obsessive themes in Mr. Allen's work, and they constitute almost the whole fabric of ''A Second Hand Memory.'' Amid the pervasive aura of doom, Eddie's moral quandary -- should he stay or should he go? -- generates little suspense. The actors, who include Dominic Chianese of ''The Sopranos'' and a particularly fine Beth Fowler, provide some leavening warmth, but it's hard to escape the feeling that Mr. Allen's characters are simply serving out their sentences before our eyes, railing against an unjust fate by incessantly flailing away at one another (2:15). Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $60.  ISHERWOOD    Last Chance    *++ 'SIN (A CARDINAL DEPOSED)' Sins come in assorted sizes, but it's hard to take the full measure of the misdeeds exposed in this sober play about the sexual-abuse scandal that unfolded in New England over the past decades. Michael Murphy's quietly disturbing play, drawn from documentary evidence, reveals with devastating clarity the dubious role that Cardinal Bernard Law, the archbishop of Boston, played in a tragedy that irreparably damaged hundreds of families and destroyed more than a few lives. The play is a theatrically unadorned re-enactment of a literal deposition given by Cardinal Law in the presence of a pair of lawyers and one of the victims of abuse pursuing a civil case against the church. The play is inevitably static. But listen closely, and a chilling drama can be detected beneath the restrained talk about notes scrawled on decades-old letters. It's the exposure of the moral and bureaucratic mechanics behind the church's failure to protect its members from the destructive acts of its priests. Perhaps also visible, underneath the strained but cordial mask of propriety presented by John Cullum, who plays Cardinal Law, is another drama, the public stripping away of a man's illusions about his moral righteousness (1:30). Clurman Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, (212) 239-6200. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $51.25.  ISHERWOOD    Movies    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.    Now Playing    'AFTER THE SUNSET' Starring Pierce Brosnan, Salma Hayek and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Brett Ratner (PG-13, 93 minutes). You'd have to search high and low to find screen lovers with less romantic chemistry than Mr. Brosnan and Ms. Hayek in ''After the Sunset,'' a jewel-heist frolic so stale it feels like a retread of a retread. Mr. Brosnan has finally reached the age of flab, and the sight of Ms. Hayek's extravagant cleavage spilling over his hairy paunch isn't especially pretty. Even by the fanciful rules of caper comedies, ''After the Sunset'' is a fraudulent entertainment. Except for the opening chase, its action sequences are strictly routine, and the overall tone strains after a wit and style that appear far beyond the director's grasp.  STEPHEN HOLDEN    'ALEXANDER' Starring Colin Farrell, Angelina Jolie and Val Kilmer. Directed by Oliver Stone (R, 173 minutes). There comes the moment in the career of many directors when they are compelled to tell the story of a great man in whose life they seem to see a glimmer of their own image. Francis Ford Coppola had Preston Tucker, the automotive innovator who tried and failed to challenge Detroit in much the same way as the filmmaker took on Hollywood, while Martin Scorsese and Mel Gibson each had Jesus. Now, Oliver Stone has Alexander the Great, the Macedonian tyrant who cut a bloody swath through the ancient world to no obvious end other than, if Mr. Stone's big, blowsy movie is to believed, get away from his kvetch of a mother. And what a kvetch she was! Mad of eye and teased of hair, Olympias, played with nose-flaring gusto by Ms. Jolie, was the mother of all monstrous mothers, a literal snake charmer whose love for her only son had the stench of incestuous passion and the tedium of the perpetual nag. For Alexander (Mr. Farrell, upstaged by an epically bad dye job), the oedipal plot would only thicken because he also loved Olympias's most loathed enemy, her husband and his father, Philip, the King of Macedon (Mr. Kilmer). The struggle between Olympias and Philip, these primordial warring female and male forces, would be reproduced in both Alexander's bisexual desires and his rapacious conquest of the feminized East. In other words, Alexander became his dad to waylay his mom.  MANOHLA DARGIS    * 'BAD EDUCATION' Starring Gael García Bernal, Fele Martínez and Javier Cámara. Directed by Pedro Almodóvar (NC-17; 110 minutes; in Spanish, with English subtitles). The great Spanish director's newest film is a delirious, headlong immersion and reinvention of film noir, a style that has lured countless film makers onto its treacherous shoals. Mr. Almodóvar, unlike other filmmakers who lose their bearings, fully understands the degree to which the genre is synonymous with fantasy and a primal longing for the forbidden. The coup de grace of ''Bad Education,'' which ricochets back and forth between 1964 and 1980, with a finale set mostly in 1977, is that here the femme fatale is a predatory transsexual named Ignacio. Once a beautiful boy soprano, he/she was abused by a priest, the principal in his Catholic boys school. As the film deepens and the characters' mistaken and multiple identities accumulate, the priest returns from the past in a new, desperate guise. ''Bad Education'' contemplates the wonder of storytelling itself and the human instinct to embroider reality to make the tales we tell more real and conclusive, if less strictly factual. It insists that stories, the stories within stories, and the fantasies they crystallize, are the best (and maybe the only) tools at our disposal for making sense of it all.  HOLDEN    'BEING JULIA' Starring Annette Bening. Directed by Istvan Szabo (R, 103 minutes). A flimsy frame surrounding a marvelous performance. As Julia Lambert, an aging star of the prewar London stage, Ms. Bening swoops from melodrama to farce with splendid hauteur and touching fragility. Julia, whose marriage to her longtime director (Jeremy Irons) has long been a primarily professional attachment, falls into an affair with Tom Fennel (Shaun Evans), a sweet-faced, penniless American who turns out to be a callow adventurer. In tracing the phases of her affair -- from rapture to heartbreak to revenge -- the film is too busy and plodding to develop an emotional core, and Mr. Evans has all the sexual magnetism of a boiled potato. The rest of the cast supports Ms. Bening gallantly, and she lifts the movie from the costume-drama doldrums by sheer dazzling force of will.  A.O. SCOTT    'BRIDGET JONES: THE EDGE OF REASON' Starring Renée Zellweger, Hugh Grant and Colin Firth. Directed by Beeban Kidron (R, 108 minutes). What was Ms. Zellweger thinking? It can't have been fun to put on all that weight, especially for a film as ghastly as this, and it sure won't be fun taking it off again. And what is the appeal of Bridget Jones? More to the point, what is the appeal of laughing at her swishing thighs, her lack of both charm and obvious intelligence? At the screening a lot of women were cackling lustily every time the camera zoomed in on Bridget's bulbous posterior, which of course looks much like the posterior of most women who don't live for Pilates and in Beverly Hills. Ms. Kidron took obvious delight in this unhappy view, too. She either really disliked her star or thinks humiliating other women is great sport. Whatever the case, you have to wonder why all these women (you go, sister!) relish the spectacle of a normally well-coiffed, highly paid Academy Award-winning actress, who dates rock stars no less, looking so bad. Unlike Sharon Maguire, who directed ''Bridget Jones's Diary,'' Ms. Kidron goes out of her way to make the character unattractive, sticking the camera under Bridget's chin and doing nothing nice with the lighting. Bridget is pleasantly plump in the first movie, as plush and appealing as an Eiderdown comforter, but here she's a greasy, bumbling, waddling train wreck. Doesn't the poor thing read fashion magazines or go shopping in London's boutiques and groovy outdoor markets? Doesn't she wash her hair?  DARGIS    'CHRISTMAS WITH THE KRANKS' Starring Tim Allen and Jamie Lee Curtis. Directed by Joe Roth (PG, 94 minutes). Lockstep suburban conformism enforced with a fascist rigor is the ugly (but admittedly sometimes funny) joke driving this family comedy with a screenplay by Chris Columbus, adapted from John Grisham's novel ''Skipping Christmas.'' The movie is as slick and treacherous as the sheet of ice its Scrooge-like protagonist (Mr. Allen) freezes in the yard of his lawn to discourage holiday panhandlers. Until he stumbles upon it in an act of giving, he doesn't realize there is only one true path to the saccharine suffocation of ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' Its name is Hemlock Street, and he happens to live on it with his wife (Ms. Curtis) and their grown daughter (Julie Gonzalo). For all you fancy-schmancy snobs who jet off to St. Bart's for the holidays, the movie has an important message, and you'd better pay attention. If you shirkers refuse to stay home and celebrate Christmas like the rest of us, we don't want you in our community.  HOLDEN    'FINDING NEVERLAND' Starring Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet. Directed by Marc Forster (PG, 108 minutes). Steeped in melancholy, the strange story of J. M. Barrie, the Victorian who wrote ''Peter Pan,'' has the makings of a marvelous tale and one doozy of a case history. Born in Scotland in 1860, Barrie was a playwright and novelist who, after meeting a family stuffed with young boys, created in 1904 a classic of children's literature. In the years since, ''Peter Pan, or the Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up'' has been revisited numerous times, as in the splendid 1952 Disney animation, and has become an emblem for everlasting youth, both healthy and less so. Mary Martin soared as Peter Pan; Michael Jackson crashed. As Barrie in ''Finding Neverland,'' a handsome-looking film about the writer and his unripe inspirations, Mr. Depp neither soars nor crashes, but moseys forward with vague purpose and actorly restraint. Based on the play by Allan Knee, ''The Man Who Was Peter Pan,'' the film mainly concerns the period during which Barrie met and befriended the widowed Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Ms. Winslet) and her brood of boys. The filmmakers work hard to let us know that it's the mother who's the more obvious focus of the writer's attention than her children and the two adult actors exchange suitably noble looks even when Ms. Winslet's décolletage threatens to play peek-a-boo. It's all terribly polite, not a little dull and remote.  DARGIS    * 'A FOND KISS' Starring Atta Yaqub and Eva Birthistle. Directed by Ken Loach (R, 104 minutes). It is small consolation that ''A Fond Kiss,'' Ken Loach's gripping Romeo-and-Juliet story of lovers from different cultures who dare to flout traditional taboos and plan to marry doesn't end in their deaths. Whether or not Casim Khan (Mr. Yaqub), a second-generation Pakistani immigrant living in Glasgow with his devoutly Moslem family, and Roison Hanlon (Ms. Birthistle), a spirited Scottish teacher in a Catholic school remain together, the movie leaves you with nagging worries about the future of any intercultural relationship once the passion cools. English-language East-West domestic dramas usually tip the scales in favor of modernity, with the high-principled, hidebound Asians, headed by a fulminating patriarch ultimately to be pitied for their rigidity and adherence to traditional ways. But ''A Fond Kiss'' is equally sympathetic to both sides.  HOLDEN    * 'THE INCREDIBLES' With the voices of Craig T. Nelson, Holly Hunter, Samuel L. Jackson and Jason Lee. Written and directed by Brad Bird (PG, 118 minutes). A family of superheroes try to fit in in the suburbs after a public backlash against costumed crime fighters has forced them into dull, ordinary lives. Mom and especially Dad -- once known as Elastigirl and Mr. Incredible -- are stuck in a midlife, middle-class malaise until a supervillain named Syndrome emerges to call them back to their old identities. Anything but dull and ordinary, this computer-animated feature has a clean and vibrant visual style and is organized around a strong, fascinating idea. Mr. Bird (''The Iron Giant'') uses the plight of the superheroes as a way to protest against the celebration of mediocrity in a world where ''everybody is special, so no one is.'' His fusion of Ayn Rand's philosophy with classic comic-book aesthetics results in a film that is witty, elegant and heartfelt. It falls short of its potential, though, when it succumbs to the imperatives of blockbuster ideology and trades in its subtlety for noise and over-familiar thrills.  SCOTT    *  'KINSEY' Starring Liam Neeson, Laura Linney and Peter Sarsgaard. Directed by Bill Condon (R, 118 minutes). Mr. Neeson is flawless as Alfred Kinsey, the zoologist whose research into human sexual behavior helped to transform American attitudes about matters of the flesh. Though it has its share of carnality, Mr. Condon's wise and witty biography is, above all, an intellectual turn-on, its romance fueled by Kinsey's scientific zeal and his ardent, almost naïve belief that knowledge is not only power, but freedom. While acknowledging his personal failings and misjudgment, the film regards its hero with affection and gratitude, and makes its case for his legacy with tact and care. Though it sometimes falls into biopic convention, explaining what it should dramatize and dramatizing what it should imply, the film is rich with humanity and insight. Crisp performances by Ms. Linney, as Kinsey's wife, and Mr. Sarsgaard, as his first research assistant bring the complexities of Kinsey's life into sharp relief.  SCOTT    'NATIONAL TREASURE' Starring Nicolas Cage. Directed by Jon Turteltaub (PG, 125 minutes). Maybe, just maybe, an 8-year-old could pick up an interest in American history from watching ''National Treasure,'' that is if the child can stay awake through this sluggish two-hour trudge through landmarks in Washington, Philadelphia and New York. It's far more likely, however, that a child who can stay awake through the movie will come away believing the bogus mythology that detonates this fanciful reality game show (a Grade C ''Amazing Race'') with a squishy thud. That mythology, derived from Freemasonry, holds that a map, drawn in invisible ink on the back of the Declaration of Independence, contains clues to the whereabouts of the Greatest Treasure Ever Told About. A more cynical (and witless, shoddy) chase for Hollywood gold is hard to imagine.  HOLDEN    'THE POLAR EXPRESS' With the voices of Tom Hanks and Michael Jeter. Peter Scolare, Nona Gaye, Eddie Deezen and Charles Fleischer. Directed by Robert Zemeckis (G, 97 minutes). Based on the 32-page children's book by Chris Van Allsburg, this new animated feature has received attention for the advanced technology employed to make the film and the heart-skipping amount of money reportedly spent to transpose the story from page to screen. I suspect that most moviegoers care more about stories and characters than how much money it took for a digitally rendered strand of hair to flutter persuasively in the wind. Nor will they care that to make ''Polar Express'' Mr. Hanks wore a little cap that transmitted a record of his movements to a computer, creating templates for five different animated characters. It's likely, I imagine, that most moviegoers will be more concerned by the eerie listlessness of those characters' faces and the grim vision of Santa Claus's North Pole compound, with interiors that look like a munitions factory and facades that seem conceived along the same oppressive lines as Coketown, the red-brick town of ''machinery and tall chimneys'' in Dickens's ''Hard Times.'' Tots surely won't recognize that Santa's big entrance in front of the throngs of frenzied elves and awe-struck children directly evokes, however unconsciously, one of Hitler's Nuremberg rally entrances in Leni Riefenstahl's ''Triumph of the Will.'' But their parents may marvel that when Santa's big red sack of toys is hoisted from factory floor to sleigh it resembles nothing so much as an airborne scrotum.  DARGIS    * 'SIDEWAYS' Starring Paul Giamatti. Directed by Alexander Payne (R, 124 minutes). The specter of a disappointed life hangs over Mr. Payne's film ''Sideways,'' casting shadows so deep and so dark it's a wonder that the story's nearly broken hero hasn't drowned in them. But Miles, beautifully played by Mr. Giamatti, hasn't yet been broken by his divorce, unpublished novels and the accumulation of everyday indignities that have helped make him the man he is. And therein lies the great cosmic joke of this heart-piercing film: without struggle and pain, Miles wouldn't be half the good and decent man he is, though he certainly might complain a little less, venture a little more. Directed by Mr. Payne, who adapted the screenplay with his long-time writing partner, Jim Taylor, from the book by Rex Pickett, ''Sideways'' is about a man on the verge of saying uncle to life. The film opens with Miles taking off with his longtime friend Jack (Thomas Haden Church) to the central California coast for an orchestrated week of wine, golf and camaraderie. Afterward, the two will motor back to reality where Jack, a B-list actor and pretty boy fast on the fade, will marry for the first time. For Miles, eagerly waiting word on the fate of yet another manuscript, the week promises a much-needed respite from his day-to-day; for Jack it's an excuse to beat a quick if temporary retreat from the future.  DARGIS    THE SPONGEBOB SQUAREPANTS MOVIE' With the voices of Tom Kenny, Clancy Brown and Rodger Bumpass. Directed by Steven Hillenburg (PG, 88 minutes). If nautical nonsense be something you wish for, then this big-screen expansion of the popular Nickelodeon show will be just the ticket. SpongeBob and his best pal Patrick set off on a rambling quest to recover a stolen crown and prevent Plankton from taking over Bikini Bottom and driving poor Mr. Krabs out of business. If none of this makes sense to you, fear not; it won't necessarily make any more after the movie is done. In any case, the point of ''SpongeBob'' is not sense but nonsense, and the film, like the series, is a giddy celebration of pure childishness, which makes it a refreshing antidote to the glowering machismo that dominates so much pop culture.  SCOTT    'A VERY LONG ENGAGEMENT' Starring Audrey Tatou. Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet (R, 133 minutes; in French, with English subtitles). If you like battleground carnage delivered with aesthetic brio, the kind that ensures that when a soldier explodes into confetti his flesh will dapple a trenchmate as decoratively as pink rosettes on a cake, this new French film will serve you nicely. Set during World War I and its immediate aftermath, and directed by the cult favorite Jean-Pierre Jeunet, the film follows the adventures of a young woman, Mathilde (Ms. Tautou) who holds fast to the hope that her young solider fiancé will return home from his apparent grave. Even when death seems to do them part, the cord of her love remains unbroken. Best known for ''Amélie,'' a modern fairy tale also starring Ms. Tautou, Mr. Jeunet is in the possession of a distinctive visual style thats part Rube Goldberg, part F.A.O. Schwarz, and generally enjoyable for about 15 minutes. Watching gears and wheels whir inside a clock, no matter how precisely calibrated the mechanism, quickly loses its appeal. With ''A Very Long Engagement,'' Mr. Jeunet has again proved himself an admirable watchmaker. Armed with an enormous bag of special-effects tricks, he recreates a bygone era with digital wizardry, manic energy, a fastidious attention to detail and only the faintest of heartbeats. Unlike children who bring even the most chewed-up teddy bear to life, however, Mr. Jeunet shows no interest in animating the characters in his dollhouse world.  DARGIS    Rock/Pop    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy rock and pop concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.    RICHARD BUCKNER, Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236. Women and booze keep letting Richard Buckner down, and his glum, scuffed-up voice is just right for songs that bring together the depressive sides of honky-tonk country and singer-songwriter confessionals. Tonight at 8, with Paul K. opening; admission is $12.  JON PARELES    * ROSANNE CASH/LARRY KIRWAN, 150 West 17th Street, Manhattan, (212) 620-5000. Rosanne Cash writes about the ache and aftermath of love with durable folky melodies, chiseled lyrics and calmly telling insights. She underplays her songs, letting them hit home quietly. In this series called ''Acoustic Cash,'' she shares the stage with fellow songwriters, talking and singing. Larry Kirwan is the songwriter behind Black 47, the New York Irish band whose songs mingle history and the multicultural present. Tonight at 7; admission is $35.  PARELES    CLAUS FEST 2004, Continental Airlines Arena, the Meadowlands, Route 120, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900. It's the season of giving as bands repay radio stations for their air time. WXRK, better known as 92.3 K-Rock, receives its tribute from an assortment of rockers including Korn, with its deep-bottomed, traumatized growls; the Guns 'n' Roses/Stone Temple Pilots merger Velvet Revolver; the earnest but upbeat Jimmy Eat World; the post-punk update of Franz Ferdinand; and the bleak, Tool-style hard rock of Chevelle. Tonight at 7; tickets are $32.92 to 52.92.  PARELES    AMY CORREIA, Fez (downstairs at the Time Cafe), 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. Ms. Correia's quavery, off-center voice isn't as fragile as it sounds. On her new album, ''Lakeville'' (Nettwerk), the characters in her songs are often barely hanging on, but there's a clarity in her details and a bluesy streak in her voice that suggests they'll hang on tightly. A. M. and Amos Lee share the bill. Tonight at 7; admission is $12.  PARELES    MARSHALL CRENSHAW, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703. Mr. Crenshaw's songs seem to roll off the guitar in a casual blend of pre-1970's styles -- folk-rock, surf-rock, country and above all the Beatles -- that put melody first. With his winsome tenor, he delves into the ways love goes right and goes wrong, from distant yearning to the aftermath of infidelity, hiding turmoil within the chiming tunes. Tomorrow night at 7:30; tickets are $15.  PARELES    THE DANIELSON FAMILE, Northsix, 66 North 6th Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103. In various configurations including the Danielson Famile (with his siblings) and Br. Danielson, Daniel Smith sings earnestly about Christian faith and the vagaries of the flesh. The low-fi songs lurch and tinkle, yelp and coo. Tonight at 9 with Kimya Dawson and P.G. Six; admission is $10.  PARELES    * ANI DiFRANCO, Count Basie Theater, 99 Monmouth Street, Red Bank, N.J., (732) 842-9000. Ms. DiFranco's articulate, uninhibited songs and poems are about staying true to her complicated self: feisty and vulnerable, polysexual, uncompromising and politically engaged, but never humorless. She can strum a guitar and sling words at hyperspeed, or swerve toward jazz and funk; for this tour, she's accompanied by Todd Sickafoose on upright bass. In business (she runs her own label, Righteous Babe Records) as in her music, she's as independent as they come. Sunday night at 8; tickets are $37.50.  PARELES    THE EAST VILLAGE OPERA COMPANY, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tyley Ross, a tenor, lovingly sings Donizetti, Verdi, Franck and Rossini, backed by everything from hard-rock to pedal steel guitar to accordion oom-pah. Cleverness reigns. Sunday night at 7 and 9; admission is $20.  PARELES    MELISSA FERRICK, The Stone Pony, 913 Ocean Avenue, Asbury Park, N.J., (732) 502-0600. Somewhere between Ani DiFranco and Melissa Etheridge, Ms. Ferrick slings an acoustic guitar and belts songs filled with bravado. Saturday night at 8; tickets are $13, $15 at the door .  PARELES    *THE FRAMES, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. The Frames, who can fill arenas in their native Ireland, are unembarrassed by sincerity, and their songs build from folky beginnings to jolts of rock to anthemic choruses that come across as joyfully heartfelt. They have a fiddle, too. Tonight at 7, with the Zincs opening, and at 9:30; admission is $15; sold out but returns may be available.  PARELES    ROBERT GORDON, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703.. After a short flirtation with 1970's punk, Mr. Gordon fell in love with rockabilly and had a hit with a remake of ''Red Hot.'' He's still twanging. Tomorrow night at 10 with the Barry Ryan Band opening; admission is $10.  PARELES    * JULIANA HATFIELD, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Ms. Hatfield's voice is usually sweet and clear, but there's a steely determination behind it. In oddly shaped, meticulous tunes, she sings about suicidal tendencies and anorexia, addiction and paranoia, masochism and obsession and heartbreak. As Ms. Hatfield's songs tell it, life is an endless round of impulsive, often self-destructive acts; she is the victim or the victimizer by turns, and most of the time she avoids self-pity. Ms. Hatfield doesn't just get mad; she gets precise. And her most recent album, ''In Exile Deo'' (Zoe), has some of the best songs of her career. Tomorrow night at 9:30; admission is $15.  PARELES    *  TH' LEGENDARY SHACK SHAKERS, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, and Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236. From Kentucky by way of Nashville, Th' Legendary Shack Shakers have come up with a twisted Southern rock that tosses together rockbilly, polka, punk, old blues, Tom Waits and lyrics that scramble the Bible and the backwoods. They're rowdy, but there's more to them than that. At Mercury Lounge tonight at 11:30, with Oakley Hall at 10:30, the Navigators at 9:30 and Dusty Wright and the Jaguars at 8:30; admission is $10. At Southpaw Sunday night at 8, with the Crevulators opening; admission is $8.  PARELES    DARLENE LOVE'S CHRISTMAS SHOW, Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 749-5838. Darlene Love was the voice on some of Phil Spector's most unforgettable productions: ''He's a Rebel,''  ''Today I Met the Boy I'm Gonna Marry'' and, on his Christmas album, ''Christmas (Baby, Please Come Home).'' She'll be belting them all with a band and choir. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $35 to $65.  PARELES    MAMAYA AFRIKA, B.B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Female singers from Africa, the Caribbean and the United States share the bill in this benefit for breast cancer awareness. They include Albita, the gutsy-voiced Cuban expatriate; the South African singer Lorraine Klaasen; Fantcha, who sings the lilting mornas of Cape Verde; Coumba Sidibe, who is steeped in the Wassoulou tradition of Mali; and six others. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $50 and $150.  PARELES    ANDERS OSBORNE, TriBeCa Rock Club, 16 Warren Street, TriBeCa, (212) 766-1070. Mr. Osborne was born in Sweden but he has done his best to become a full-fledged New Orleans rocker, teaming up with brass bands and making his guitar moan the blues. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, with Mary McBride opening; tickets are $15 in advance, $20 the day of the show.  PARELES    * EDDIE PALMIERI AND LA PERFECTA II/SPANISH HARLEM ORCHESTRA, Aaron Davis Hall, City College, West 135th Street and Convent Avenue, Hamilton Heights, (212) 650-7100. This double bill looks back to a golden age of salsa in the 1960's and 70's. In the early 60's, the pianist Eddie Palmieri's aggressive, stripped-down Conjunto La Perfecta, with its front line of two trombones and flute, revolutionized the sound of Latin music. La Perfecta II revisits the old repertory with the benefit of Mr. Palmieri's decades of experience as both dance-music dynamo and jazz iconoclast. Anyone who has heard a salsa band in New York City has probably seen some of the members of the Spanish Harlem Orchestra: they're the virtuosic journeymen who are among New York City's great musical resources. As the Spanish Harlem Orchestra, they reclaim salsa classics under the direction of the keyboardist Oscar Hernandez. Tonight at 7:30; tickets are $25 to $35.  PARELES    * MARIANNE PILLSBURY, Arlene's Grocery, 95 Stanton Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-1633, On her debut album, ''The Wrong Marianne'' (www.mariannepillsbury.com), Marianne Pillsbury is as frank as Liz Phair and as tuneful and upbeat as the Go-Go's, dissecting romantic disasters and then bouncing back with light-hearted choruses. She's as tough as she is irrepressible. Tonight at 8; admission is $7.  PARELES    SASHA, Crobar, 530 West 28th Street, near 10th Avenue, Chelsea, (212) 629-9000. Tonight, this wildly popular progessive-house D.J. is to begin a monthly residency at the gargantuan Chelsea nightclub Crobar. It's a revival of sorts: the promoters are clearly hoping to duplicate the success Sasha achieved with his partner, John Digweed, in the late 1990's, when the two had a monthly gig at another gargantuan Chelsea nightclub: Twilo, which closed three years ago. Don't expect the dawning of a new era, but do expect a good party: Sasha has a knack for pleasing huge crowds without (for the most part) pandering to them. He eschews both the obvious and the unusual, topping his steady, thumping beats with complicated electronic patterns that slowly decay and mutate. Tonight after 10, with Jimmy Van M and Sean Cusick; advance tickets are $30.  KELEFA SANNEH    LOS STRAITJACKETS, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. With enough concepts for an extra band or two, Los Staitjackets play twangy surf-rock, often perform in Mexican wrestling masks and have plenty of Christmas songs (they released a Christmas album in 2002). Sunday night at 8, with the World Famous Pontani Sisters opening; tickets are $15.  PARELES    TRASHCAN SINATRAS, Fez (downstairs at the Time Cafe), 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. Tuneful pop survives in Scotland, where the Trashcan Sinatras reach back to the 1960's and 70's, particularly folk-rock and the Beach Boys, for songs that chime and harmonize about wistful yearnings. The group is playing an acoustic set. Tomorrow and Sunday nights at 6:30; admission is $15.  PARELES    * SOPHISTICATED & SEXY, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 247-0200. Now long removed from their pioneering quartet Jodeci, K-Ci and JoJo continue to sing some of the most extreme R & B on the planet -- and, when they feel like it, some of the most suavely traditional. With a neck-flexing moan or a throat-scratching growl, they can conjure up a desire so intense it's nearly indistinguishable from terror, then turn around and croon a winsome ballad. The duo headlines Sophisticated & Sexy, a party that also features the comedian Capone and the hip-hop pioneer DJ Hollywood. If it's half as entertaining as the bombastic invitation (which warns, ''Absolutely no denim,'' and promises, ''We leave the building at 4 a.m.''), it'll be a riot. Tomorrow night, doors open at 9, with a complimentary buffet at 10:30; tickets are $35 in advance and -- inevitably -- ''More at the door!''  SANNEH    EL TRI, Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Midtown, (212) 564-4882. El Tri, a long-running rock band from Mexico City, has been voraciously and good-humoredly assimilating rock from north of the border, spanning blues-rock, country-pop and arena anthems while adding its own jaunty vocals and jocular observations for a big, beery good time. Sunday night at 6; tickets are $45.  PARELES    VORDUL MEGA, Sin-é, 148-150 Attorney Street, near Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212) 388-0077. In 2001, the local duo Cannibal Ox released ''The Cold Vein'' (Definitive Jux), an appealingly labyrinthine debut album that matched thick, jagged beats with dense, murky, half-speed rhymes that you didn't hear so much as absorb. Vordul Mega, half of Cannibal Ox, released a solo debut, ''The Revolution of Yung Havoks'' (Nature Sounds), that isn't nearly as dense, nor as absorbing: once he spelunked, but now he mainly just rambles. Sunday night at 8, with Billy Woods, Monsta Island Czars, Karneige, Akir and more; admission is $8.  SANNEH    DAR WILLIAMS, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. Joan Baez loves Ms. Williams's songs, which apply the style of 1960's coffeehouse folkies to the ever more complicated 21st century. With meticulous imagery and forthright melodies, Ms. Williams examines tangled loves and friendships along with the mixed blessings of adulthood. Tonight at 8, with Anna Egge opening; tickets are $30.  PARELES    VANESSA WILLIAMS, Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway at 46th Street, (212) 730-8200. Vanessa Williams's career as a pop and Broadway crooner includes two Christmas albums, which should supply much of her material for these concerts. Tonight through Sunday at 8; tickets are $35 to $85.  PARELES    Cabaret    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music.    BARBARA CARROLL, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. The Lady of a Thousand Songs is back in the Oak Room for Sunday brunch and evening performances. This elegant, red-headed pianist and singer is a poised entertainer whose impeccable pianism belongs to the school of jazz that maintains a sense of classical decorum at the keyboard. Even when swinging out, she remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Vocally, she belongs to the conversational tradition of Mabel Mercer with a style that's blasé but never cold. Sunday at 2 and 8 p.m. Cover: $55 at 2, including brunch at noon; $80 at 8, with dinner served at 6:30.  STEPHEN HOLDEN    BABY JANE DEXTER, Helen's, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-0609. Ms. Dexter, a natural rock-blues belter who refrains from full-tilt shouting, roams all over the place, from Cole Porter to R.E.M. to Rod McKuen to the Rolling Stones, in her new show ''Bread and Gravy.'' If her bold re-evaluations of songs don't always work, they tear away the associations crusted on songs we think we know to reveal new avenues of interpretation. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9:15. Cover: $25 and a $15 minimum.  HOLDEN    * ANDREA MARCOVICCI, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. Authentic glamour may be an oxymoron. But Ms. Marcovicci becomes its embodiment when she performs. In her new show, ''Andrea Sings Astaire,'' she suggests a latter-day hybrid of Audrey Hepburn, the most gracious, elegant and beautifully spoken of Hollywood princesses, and Mabel Mercer, that ruefully witty, all-wise, healing muse of a thousand romantic sorrows. Like Mercer's, her singing is really speech-song executed with an elocutionary flourish and stylized acting. The show weaves music, biography and analysis of Astaire iconography into a definitive career summary. It focuses, in particular, on his relationships with the composers who wrote for him. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $60, with a $55 dinner required at the early shows and a $20 minimum at the late shows.  HOLDEN    * 'SINGING ASTAIRE,' Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, (212) 581-3080. With Eric Comstock, Hilary Kole and Christopher Gines. The vocal trio that created the smart revue ''Our Sinatra'' has outdone itself with ''Singing Astaire,'' a lightly swinging, 70-minute compendium of songs and lore associated with Fred Astaire. Suave and dry, and fleet on the piano, Mr. Comstock is a close stylistic relative of his idol, while Ms. Kole's pop-jazz singing has a Ginger Rogersesque edge. Mr. Gines fills in the difference with creamy vocal custard: witty, informative, and fast-paced. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11. Cover: $40.  HOLDEN    BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 570-7189. After announcing his semi-retirement last year from performing at the Cafe Carlyle, this legendary singer and pianist changed his mind and is back in action for another season. Mr. Short never fails to conjure ebullient party spirits and has impeccable taste in songs. Expect to hear at least one of his three signature songs, ''Guess Who's in Town?,'' ''Just One of Those Things'' and ''Romance in the Dark,'' along with something by one of the two Dukes (Ellington and Vernon). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:45 and 10:45. Cover: $95.  HOLDEN    Jazz    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.    * ANDY BEY, Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater, Symphony Space, 95th Street at Broadway, Upper West Side, (212) 864-5400. Mr. Bey possesses a skyscraper voice: bass-baritone lows, accurate falsetto highs. A singer and pianist, he is ferociously talented, and his comeback over the last decade is one of the more welcome developments in jazz; his new album, ''American Song'' (Savoy Jazz), bears this out. He plays two shows with his trio, tonight and tomorrow at 8:30; tickets are $21; 64+ and students, $16.  BEN RATLIFF    TERENCE BLANCHARD QUINTET, Miller Theater, Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, (212) 854-7799. Terence Blanchard has been making changes in his groups lately, and with his last album, ''Bounce'' (Blue Note), he added to his group a guitarist from Benin, Lionel Loueke, who uses finger tapping and electronic techniques that add something new to the straight-ahead jazz context. Tomorrow at 8 pm; tickets are $25.  RATLIFF    JOEY DeFRANCESCO, Dizzy's Club Coca Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 258-9595. Mr. DeFrancesco is a Philadelphia-based Hammond organ player who has put in his time learning with the masters of the instrument; he has a tough, churning, rhythmic sound, and his group includes the tenor saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman. Sets through Sunday at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30.  RATLIFF    * MARK TURNER AND FLY, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212)  242-1063. An excellent co-operative trio, with the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner, the bassist Larry Grenadier and the drummer Jeff Ballard. Some of its music sounds chamberlike, some Latin, some funky; some, with breathtaking long-line improvisations and tight group communication, seems to propose a new model for saxophone trios. Tonight at 9 and 10:30; admission is $15 per set.  RATLIFF    BILL FRISELL QUINTET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-4037. You have to give it to Bill Frisell for the long haul: having come out of the fairly fragmentary downtown music scene of the 1980's, he is still building an audience and working on his own ideal music, sometimes gentle or earthy Americana, sometimes harmonically complex, and unarguably jazz. He can also, on occasion, make your jaw drop with his guitar playing. This group augments his regular trio (including the bassist Tony Scherr and the drummer Kenny Wolleson) with the soft-toned trumpeter Ron Miles and the tenor saxophonist Greg Tardy. Sets through Sunday night are at 9 and 11, with a 12:30 set tomorrow; cover charge is $30.  RATLIFF    JOHN HICKS, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-3626. A presence in New York since the 1970's, Mr. Hicks is a steamroller of a mainstream-jazz pianist, loading up the music with thick chords as if he wanted to do McCoy Tyner one better. Sets are tonight and tomorrow at 8, 10 and midnight; cover charge is $20.  RATLIFF    * GRETCHEN PARLATO, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. The winner of the recent Thelonious Monk Competition for jazz vocals, Ms. Parlato is a newcomer of great promise: in standards, bossa novas and originals, through long tones and subtle inflections of rhythm, she deeply enters the musical field of her band, directing from within rather than throwing her voice out front. Tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; tickets are $15 per set.  RATLIFF    * DIANNE REEVES, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592. Jazz singers these days seem more likely to find their information in the restraint and mystery of bossa nova than in the unapologetic splendor of, say, Sarah Vaughan. Maybe it's because they feel that reticent music implies modernity more quickly. If so, Dianne Reeves is their opposite: she's only lightly concerned with reticence. She has an enormous (and Vaughan-inspired) voice, and an enormous talent, and she offers it up to stun her audience. Sets through Sunday night at 8 and 10:30; cover charge is $25-$37.50.  RATLIFF    * PHAROAH SANDERS-KENNY GARRETT QUARTET, Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121. When this pair of saxophonists -- both influenced by Coltrane, but Mr. Sanders from the late period and Mr. Garrett from the middle period -- got together last year, with Jeff (Tain) Watts on drums, it might not have looked like much on paper: another reshuffling of good players. But they seemed to set one another off like rockets. Here was Mr. Garrett, playing alto with his rabbitlike speed and remarkable rhythmic articulation; here was Mr. Sanders playing a lush and cataclysmic form of free jazz, with high overtones seeping into low runs, bunches of notes smeared together into one: an effusive, thoroughly worked-out language of pure sound. Sets through Sunday night at 8 and 10 with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $32.50 to $35.  RATLIFF    LUCIANA SOUZA WITH ED SIMON, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8770. Ms. Souza, the jazz mezzo-soprano, who grew up in Brazil, has an alert, clear voice, with undertones of calm conversation and the sound of a well-rested intelligence. She is also a composer of intriguing art songs, and recently she set Pablo Neruda poems to music for an album on Sunnyside called ''Neruda.'' She'll perform that music here, in duets with the pianist Mr. Simon. Tomorrow at 7:30; cover charge is $20.  RATLIFF    * JACKY TERRASSON TRIO WITH RAVI COLTRANE, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. With his new group (Sean Smith on bass and Eric Harland on drums), Mr. Terrasson has gotten back to what he does best: creating stunning, fizzy trio music, absolutely flexible in form as it breaks up into pieces and then coheres again; it has a low-impact virtuosity and a likable enthusiasm. Ravi Coltrane, on tenor and soprano saxophones, is a guest with the band this week. Sets through Sunday night are at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $25 to $30.  RATLIFF    LARRY WILLIS TRIO, Smoke, 2751 Broadway at 106th Street, (212)  864-6662. Larry Willis has played for years with Roy Hargrove's quintet and Jerry Gonzalez's Fort Apache Band, and he is a widely literate musician. But this gig is straight-ahead jazz, New York-style, with Buster Williams and Al Foster. Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $20.  RATLIFF    Classical    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera and classical music events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent classical music and opera performances: nytimes.com/music.    Opera    'AIDA' The Metropolitan Opera can excel on occasion in making a spectacle of itself; at least the spectacle is warranted in Verdi's ''Aida,'' which was originally conceived as grand opera. Lots of different singers are wafting through this season's revival; they include Norma Fantini as Aida, Irina Mishura as Amneris, and Ambrogio Maestri, who made his company debut earlier in the run, as Amonasro. When he's on, Franco Farina is a ringing Radames; and the excellent Marcello Viotti conducts. Add a few armies of dancers and horses and you could have a fine old time. Tomorrow afternoon at 1, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $145.  ANNE MIDGETTE    'I VESPRI SICILIANI' The convoluted story and clunky libretto to Verdi's ''Vespri Siciliani'' has probably kept this mature and stirring opera from gaining repertory status. So it's good to have this neglected and important work back at the Metropolitan Opera after 22 years, a revival of John Dexter's grimly abstract 1974 production. In the impassioned and stylish performance by the conductor Frédéric Chaslin, ''I Vespri Siciliani'' emerges as a musically distinguished opera that, with its French inflections, anticipates Verdi's noble masterpiece ''Don Carlos.'' Don't fret if the story, based on the 1282 uprising and massacre by the people of Palermo, Sicily, against their hated French occupiers, seems implausible. Just let yourself get swept away by the music. The cast includes the husky-voiced (and husky-framed) tenor Francisco Casanova, the elegant baritone Leo Nucci and the stentorian bass Samuel Ramey. The Romanian soprano Nelly Miricioiu takes over the role of Elena from Sondra Radvanovsky. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $35 to $200.  ANTHONY TOMMASINI    'TANNHÄUSER' At 50, the German dramatic tenor Peter Seiffert, who has a major career in Europe, has finally made his Metropolitan Opera debut in the daunting title role of Wagner's ''Tannhäuser,'' a revival of Otto Schenk's handsomely realistic 1977 production. For Met fans it was worth the wait. Mr. Seiffert had all the power and stamina you could want from a Wagnerian tenor, and, rarer, true tenorial colorings and impressive vocal agility. Though he has a barrel-chested physique, he gives a charismatic, physically nimble and sympathetic portrayal of the medieval knight and song minstrel torn between the erotic pleasures of Venus and the idealized love of Elisabeth. Thomas Hampson brings the elegance of the fine German lieder singer he is to his distinguished and vocally robust portrayal of Wolfram. Mark Elder conducts a lithe and vividly colored performance. Since opening night, though, new artists have stepped into the two leading female roles. Petra-Maria Schnitzer sings Elisabeth and Elizabeth Bishop sings Venus. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $40 to $215.  TOMMASINI    Classical Music    ARDITTI QUARTET This British string quartet, one of the most polished and adventurous new-music ensembles currently playing, offers a program that promises, characteristically, to be both arduous and rewarding. Included are Conlon Nancarrow's String Quartet No. 3, Elliott Carter's String Quartet No. 5, Gyorgy Ligeti's String Quartet No. 2 and the New York premiere of Helmut Lachenmann's String Quartet No. 3 (''Grido''). Tomorrow at 7:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $20 to $32.  ALLAN KOZINN    THE ASSADS The Brazilian brothers Sérgio and Odair Assad have been regarded as one of the world's pre-eminent guitar duos ever since their first recordings were released in the mid-1970's, when they were barely out of their teens. Their program on Sunday includes selections from Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco's ''Well-Tempered Guitars'' (Op. 199) and from Leo Brouwer's ''Danzas Concertantes,'' as well as Rodrigo's Tonadilla, Sérgio Assad's Suite Brasileira and transcriptions of works by Scarlatti, Ravel, Egberto Gismonti, Hermeto Pascoal and others. Tomorrow at 8, the 92nd Street Y, at 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $40.  KOZINN    BARGEMUSIC Moored in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, this intimate floating concert hall is a charming place to hear solo recitals and chamber music while rocking gently on the waves of the East River. Because of space restrictions, you don't often hear symphonies on the Barge, though tonight the American pianist Jeffrey Biegel will offer Beethoven's Fifth (in Liszt's arrangement) from the keyboard, along with works by Grieg and Gershwin. Tomorrow night and Sunday are more typical Barge programs with the violinist and artistic director Mark Peskanov joined by Steven Beck (piano) and Dmitry Kouzov (cello) in music by Haydn, Beethoven and Rachmaninoff. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday afternoon at 4, Fulton Ferry Landing, under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35; students, $25.  JEREMY EICHLER    MEASHA BRUEGGERGOSMAN This young Canadian soprano comes trailing raves, some of them comparing her with Jessye Norman. The comparison comes too easily, since Ms. Brueggergosman is also black and built on a large frame, but her CD of Barber's wonderful ''Knoxville: Summer of 1915'' and other works reveals a major talent. Here she sings more Americana, songs by Copland and William Bolcom, as well as works by Ravel, Joseph Marx, Xavier Montsalvatge and Britten. J. J. Penna is the pianist. Tonight at 7:30, Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $25.  JAMES R. OESTREICH    * CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER This weekend, the Chamber Music Society presents the first American performances of ''Pulse Shadows,'' a large-scale work by the distinguished British composer Harrison Birtwistle. Running more than an hour, the piece consists of interwoven movements from two discrete compositions -- ''Nine Movements for String Quartet'' and ''Nine Settings of Celan.'' The second of the two works is based on the writing of Paul Celan, the Romanian-born Jew whose rugged and often surreal poetry treated World War II and the Holocaust with enormous power. Among the selected texts is ''Todesfuge,'' Celan's most famous poem, which will be sung by the soprano Lisa Saffer. Other performers include the Flux Quartet, the cellist Fred Sherry, the bassist Edgar Meyer, the violist Paul Neubauer and the clarinetist David Shifrin. Reinbert de Leeuw conducts, and Mr. Birtwistle will be on hand for post-performance discussions. Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788. Tickets: $27.50 to $48, student rush $10.  EICHLER    * CHARLES CURTIS AND ALECK KARIS If the term ''avant-garde'' ceases to apply to deceased artists, Morton Feldman's long, thoughtful and detailed music has to be described with simple terms like ''beauty.'' Often inspired by visual artists, Feldman had antique carpets in mind in ''Patterns in a Chromatic Field,'' an 80-minute work that reflects the subtle variations in old dyes with microtonal writing. The cellist Charles Curtis, a new-music specialist whose past collaborators have ranged from Rudolf Firkusny to LaMonte Young, and the pianist Aleck Karis, whose credits include Speculum Musicae, recorded the piece for Tzadik Records this year, and are performing it live this weekend. Tomorrow night at 7:30, Great Hall at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street, East Village, (212) 279-4200. Tickets: $20, $15 for students and 65+.  MIDGETTE    * CONTINUUM The Estonian composer Arvo Pärt is the most renowned of the so-called mystical minimalists, but he also has a tendency to split audiences, with some listeners finding his spare and often repetitive idiom to be breathtakingly beautiful in its simplicity while others find it merely simplistic. Both views may be based on an incomplete sense of his oeuvre, which is in fact broad and diverse enough to surprise both fans and detractors. For this reason, we can welcome this Pärt retrospective performed by the dependable Continuum ensemble, featuring lesser-known vocal works (''Wallfahrtslied'' and ''Es sang vor langen Jahren''), larger ensemble works (''Silouans Song'' and ''Trisagion'') and chamber music (the Passacaglia for Violin and Piano, among others). The ensemble has a good track-record with Mr. Pärt's music and this concert should be eye-opening. Sunday at 3 p.m., Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, (212) 772-4448. Tickets: $15 to $25, students $10.  EICHLER    GRAMERCY TRIO The members of the Gramercy Trio have busy musical lives outside this ensemble. The acclaimed Boston-based pianist Randall Hodgkinson has a wide-ranging career and is a regular at the Bargemusic concerts in Brooklyn. The cellist Jonathan Miller is a 30-year veteran of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the founding director of the Boston Artists Ensemble. The violinist Sharan Leventhal is a concerto soloist, chamber music player, teacher and champion of contemporary music. Yet, all three are deeply committed to the Gramercy Trio, which plays a typically adventurous program on Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall with works by Turina, Schnittke, Schumann and a new score by the composer Fred Hersch, who draws from the jazz and classical traditions. Sunday at 3 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, (212) 501-3303. Tickets: $15.  TOMMASINI    SIMON KEENLYSIDE AND JULIUS DRAKE Simon Keenlyside, the fine British baritone, showed one side of his range as a performer at Lincoln Center two seasons ago in Trisha Brown's staging of Schubert's ''Winterreise,'' in which he demonstrated that he can dance as well as sing. This year, he's returning to a more conventional corner of the arena, offering a program of classic lieder and melodies. There's nothing here not to like, as long as you like Schubert, Brahms, Mahler and Ravel (whose ''Histoires naturelles,'' with their amusing portraits of various animals, are always a good final set); and Julius Drake is a worthy partner as his accompanist. Sunday afternoon at 2, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5050. Tickets: $48.  MIDGETTE    'LOST OBJECTS' This latest collaboration by the founders of Bang on a Can -- the composers Michael Gordon, Julia Wolfe and David Lang -- is a theatrical rumination on people and things that have been left behind in the sweep of history and civilization. The subjects, touched on in a libretto by Deborah Artman, include everything from extinct species and languages to abandoned technologies and lost rituals. The music is performed by Concerto Köln, a period instrument band that normally performs Baroque music, along with vocal soloists and a choir, the Virtuoso Singers. The staging is by the filmmaker François Girard, with sets by François Seguin and live remixing by DJ Spooky. Tonight and Tomorrow at 7:30. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $20 to $60.  KOZINN    NANCARROW AT THE PIANO Conlon Nancarrow's most interesting music is played by a machine (the player piano) not people, but musicians are pursuing Nancarrow as a human interest story this season at the Miller Theater. Tonight Christopher Taylor, one of the more ardent explorers of new music on the piano, takes up four of his pieces and surrounds them with contemporaries like Bartok, Ives, Adams and Ligeti. The music starts at 8 p.m. at the Miller Theater, 2960 Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-1633. Tickets are $20.  BERNARD HOLLAND    NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC AND NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC CHAMBER MUSIC Last week, with his first guest conducting appearance of the New York Philharmonic's season, David Robertson again proved that he is one of the most accomplished, dynamic and interesting musicians on the scene. For his second program this weekend Mr. Robertson offers something new, Steve Reich's Triple Quartet, a Philharmonic first, and something familiar, Beethoven's Eighth Symphony. The brilliant German violinist Christian Tetzlaff will also be the soloist in Bartok's Violin Concerto No. 2. But that's not all for Mr. Tetzlaff, who will join select players from the orchestra for a Sunday afternoon program of chamber music at the 92nd Street Y, with works by Mozart, Debussy and Dvorak. New York Philharmonic: Today at 2 p.m. and tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $22 to $90. New York Philharmonic Chamber Music: Sunday at 3 p.m., 92nd Street Y (92nd Street and Lexington Avenue), (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $40.  TOMMASINI    NEW YORK YOUTH SYMPHONY New music, as well as new talent, is a focus of the New York Youth Symphony, which includes a composition program among its various youth-based activities. This weekend it showcases its young performers in a work by a young composer, Joshua Penman, whose ''Songs the Plants Taught Us'' will have its premiere. More veteran talents are also on display: Glenn Dicterow, concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, is the soloist in Prokofiev's Second Violin Concerto and the final piece, a real showcase for the young players in the orchestra, is the Brahms Second Symphony. Sunday afternoon at 2, Carnegie Hall, (212) 581-5933. Tickets: $7 to $55.  MIDGETTE    ORPHEUS WITH UTE LEMPER This potent German cabaret singer may have enlarged her following with roles in musicals such as ''Chicago'' and ''Cabaret,'' but she first made her name singing the tartly expressive music of interwar Berlin, and especially the songs of Kurt Weill. She returns to this bread-and-butter repertory in a program this weekend with the conductorless Orpheus chamber orchestra. In addition to the music of Weill, Ms. Lemper will sing songs by Eisler and Brel as well as lesser known selections in Yiddish, Hebrew and Arabic. Orpheus will add to the mix Schulhoff's jazzy Suite for Chamber Orchestra and Schoenberg's dark Chamber Symphony No. 2, begun in 1906 and completed in exile in 1939. Tomorrow night at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $30 to $88.  EICHLER    PAULA ROBISON This excellent flutist has become an institution within an institution in her annual series at the Met Museum. This year she takes on ''The Great Vivaldi,'' with music that may be better suited than most to the museum's acoustically suspect Temple of Dendur. Here is an array of concertos for chamber orchestra and solo instruments, including flutes, trumpets and guitar. A concert in March completes the series. Tomorrow at 7 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $55.  OESTREICH    KATHLEEN SUPOVÉ An enterprising new-music pianist who invariably assembles interesting and often provocative programs, Ms. Supové is offering ''The John Adams-Louis Andriessen Jukebox: In Shuffle Mode'' this weekend. The three-concert recombinant program draws on the piano and chamber works of Mr. Adams, the American post-Minimalist composer who has become ubiquitous lately, and Mr. Andriessen, a Dutch composer whose work has touched on a variety of styles. Each night of this series, Ms. Supové shuffles the works, sometimes offering the same piece in different versions (Mr. Adams's ''Phrygian Gates,'' for example, is heard all three nights, but on Sunday it is performed in a ''Remix Version,'' a collaboration with the sound designer and singer Dafna Naphtali). In addition to Ms. Naftali, Ms. Supové's collaborators will include Vijay Iyer, a composer and computer performer, and Randall Woolf, a composer who will be operating CD turntables. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 7:30, the Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101. Tickets: $12.  KOZINN    Dance    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent dance performances:  nytimes.com/dance.    * BALLET HISPANICO Tina Ramirez and her vibrant dancers have proved that classical ballet and Latin social dancing go very well together, in a way that says a good deal about each discipline. The company will perform ''Night Club,'' a dramatic trilogy, set to Latin music and choreographed by Graciela Daniele, Alexandre Magno and Sergio Trujillo (tonight and tomorrow and Sunday nights). Peter Pucci's new ''Eternamente y Un Dia'' (''Forever and a Day''), which focuses on Mexican history and is set to Mexican folk songs, will be performed on a matinee program that also includes Ramón Oller's ''Bury Me Standing,'' which celebrates the Gypsy and is set to Gypsy, Spanish and European folk songs. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $45.  JENNIFER DUNNING    DODGE DANCE COMPANY AND THEATER OF DREAMS The two troupes will present an evening of dance and theater called ''Dream Street,'' which is intended to remind audiences of the talents possessed by performers with disabilities. Several of the pieces draw on traditional African dance, hip-hop and poetry by Maya Angelou. Tonight at 7:30; tomorrow at 12:30 p.m., BRIC Studio, 57 Rockwell Place, Brooklyn, (212) 273-6312. Tickets: $15; $10 for students.  DUNNING    HISKE DOOPER AND MICHOU SZABO Ms. Dooper, a modern dance choreographer from Rotterdam who has also trained at the Merce Cunningham school, will present ''Faja Lobi,'' a new dance for eight women that examines love. Mr. Szabo, a pianist and filmmaker as well as a choreographer, will perform in two new trios he created to music by Mark Coniglio and Guy Yarden. Tonight at 9; tomorrow at 8 p.m., Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street at Washington Street, West Village, (212) 978-3729. Tickets: $12.  DUNNING    'FLAMENCO FIESTA' Andrea del Conte Danza España and the guest artists Oscar Valero and José Junco celebrate the company's 25th anniversary, through Dec. 12, in a theater whose intimacy approximates a prime condition for viewing this age-old dance form. Today (and Thursdays and Fridays through Dec. 11) at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays (through Dec. 12) at 4 p.m., Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 729-3880. Tickets: $30; $27 for students and 65+; $25 (Thursdays).  DUNNING    * FRESH MEAT FESTIVAL This festival of dance, theater, puppetry and music opens with the sleepily subversive Clarinda MacLow's ''Comic Blunders,'' which she describes as darkly comic solo rituals. Ms. MacLow shares the program with two musicians, Dafna Naphtali and Hans Tammen, who plays something called the endangered guitar. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., Chocolate Factory Theater, 5-49 49th Avenue at Vernon Bouevard, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 482-7069. Tickets: $15.  DUNNING    LIZ GERRING DANCE COMPANY In her new ''Tonight Clearing, Tomorrow Clear,'' Liz Gerring uses abstract movement derived from an emotional base to suggest that despite the cloudiness of the world today, there can be clarity in the future. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 p.m., Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 868-4444. Tickets: $15.  JACK ANDERSON    * ERICK HAWKINS DANCE COMPANY Katherine Duke, a former lead dancer with the company, has put together a program of excerpts from Hawkins's ''Black Lake'' and ''Greek Dreams, With Flute.'' The evening is dedicated to the late Ralph Dorazio, a founding and important collaborator of Hawkins, whose sculptural sets and props captured and enhanced the choreographer's distinctive blend of delicacy and power. The program, a fund-raiser for the company, also includes an excerpt from Lucia Dlugoszewski's ''Radical Ardent.'' Tonight at 7:30., Rose Studio, 10th floor, Rose Building, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, (845) 216-2214. Admission is by a donation of $35 at the door.  DUNNING    SAM KIM AND LUCIANA ACHUGAR Ms. Kim and Ms. Achugar have performed with interesting modernists, including Sara Rudner, DD Dorvillier, Susan Rethorst and Wil Swanson. The new works on their shared program sound provocative, too. Ms. Kim's ''Vince and Alison'' is named for the founders of the pop band Yaz. In Ms. Achugar's ''Super Natural Return to Love,'' six women suggesting a Greek chorus examine the oppression inherent in homogeneity. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Manhattan, (212) 924-0077. Tickets: $20.  DUNNING    MOVEMENT RESEARCH IMPROVISATION FESTIVAL This annual event brings together a host of dancers in solos, duets and group improvisations in which performance skills are challenged by the wild unpredictability of each risk-taking moment. Tonight and Sunday night at 8:30, Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $12.  ANDERSON    'NEWSTEPS' This series for newish choreographers will showcase dances by Christal Brown, Naoko Morita, Sari Nordman, Nora Stephens and AKRNYM, a collaboration of the choreographers Hannah Ramsey and Amber Hirsch and the filmmaker Jason Senk. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Mulberry Street Theater, 70 Mulberry Street and Bayard Street, Little Italy, (212) 349-0126. Tickets: $12.
