Tonight at 8, with the former Terror Squad member Cuban Link; tickets are $35.  SANNEH    EDDIE AND GERALD LEVERT, Westbury Music Fair, 960 Brush Hollow Road, Westbury, L.I., (516) 334-0800. This concert pairs Eddie Levert, who was one of the gospel-charged soul singers in the O'Jays, with his son Gerald, who plays the rhythm-and-blues Casanova with alternating promises of fidelity and bedroom skills. Tonight at 8; tickets are $56.50.  PARELES    * LUNA/PALOMAR, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Embracing the legacy of two-guitar New York bands from the Velvet Underground to Television, Luna applies the dynamics of strum, drone and build to Dean Wareham's tales of longing and decadence. As Mr. Wareham sings about high-toned parties, aimless roadtrips and creeping paranoia, the songs start out cool, but the writhing, swelling guitars reveal the obsessions within them. The band is on its final tour, to end early next year. Whimsy and sinew co-exist nicely in the lean, peppy pop-rock of Palomar, a three-woman, one-man band whose songs jump from blithe choruses to wiry guitar patterns to hefty distortion, all at the service of the lyrics' articulate ambivalence. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $18.75 in advance, $20 day of the show.  PARELES    * BOB MOULD, Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103. As the main songwriter for Husker Du, Bob Mould wrapped troubled thoughts in blaring, unstoppable guitars. Since then, he has veered between melodic punk-rock with Sugar and more introspective songs under his own name. Tonight at 9, with Alex Dezen of the Damnwells opening; admission is $17.  PARELES    O.A.R., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-1224 . A little reggae, a little folk-rock, a lot of word-of-mouth and O.A.R., an Ohio band whose initials stand for Of a Revolution, has become a college-circuit favorite. Despite its name, O.A.R. is more concerned with romance than politics; it plays easy-strumming three-chord songs suitable for dorm parties, calling for audience participation on choruses like ''Naked with you all night long.'' John Butler is an Australian guitarist who, like Ben Harper, turns thoughtful songs into guitar and slide-guitar excursions. Tonight and tomorrow at 6:30, with the John Butler Trio opening tonight and the Virginia Coalition opening tomorrow; tickets are $30.  PARELES    * STRAYLIGHT RUN, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. An emo concert headlined by Straylight Run, the Long Island piano-rock act that includes a pair of former Taking Back Sunday members. The band's self-titled debut album (released last month by Victory Records) has a few too many mild ballads, but the members have a knack for writing big choruses that are just unpredictable enough to keep you listening. Expect a roaring sing-along to ''Existentialism on Prom Night,'' which includes a shameless -- and clever -- refrain that begs for crowd participation: ''Sing like you think no one's listening.'' Sunday night at 7, with Hot Rod Circuit, Northstar and Say Anything; tickets are $13.  SANNEH    * CHRIS WHITLEY, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Chris Whitley is steeped in the blues: not good-timey bar-band music but steely, tormented reflections on sin and self-destruction, betrayal and redemption. As he sings about a world of uncertainty and pain, his voice slides while his slide-guitar moans along. Tomorrow night at 8, with Paul Brill opening; tickets are $15 in advance, $17 tomorrow.  PARELES    Cabaret    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music.    BARBARA CARROLL, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. The Lady of a Thousand Songs is back in the Oak Room for Sunday brunch and evening performances. This elegant, red-headed pianist and singer is a poised entertainer whose impeccable pianism belongs to the school of jazz that maintains a sense of classical decorum at the keyboard. Even when swinging out, she remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Vocally, she belongs to the conversational tradition of Mabel Mercer with a style that's blasé but never cold. Sunday at 2 and 8 p.m. Cover: $55 at 2, including brunch at noon; $80 at 8, with dinner served at 6:30.  STEPHEN HOLDEN    * ANDREA MARCOVICCI, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 419-9331. Authentic glamour may be an oxymoron. But Ms. Marcovicci becomes its embodiment when she performs. In her new show, ''Andrea Sings Astaire,'' she suggests a latter-day hybrid of Audrey Hepburn, the most gracious, elegant and beautifully spoken of Hollywood princesses, and Mabel Mercer, that ruefully witty, all-wise, healing muse of a thousand romantic sorrows. Like Mercer's, her singing is really speech-song executed with an elocutionary flourish and stylized acting. The show weaves music, biography and analysis of Astaire iconography into a definitive career summary. It focuses, in particular, on his relationships with the composers who wrote for him. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $60, with a $55 dinner required at the early shows and a $20 minimum at the late shows.  HOLDEN    BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 570-7189. After announcing his semi-retirement last year from performing at the Cafe Carlyle, this legendary singer and pianist changed his mind and is back in action for another season. Mr. Short never fails to conjure ebullient party spirits and has impeccable taste in songs. Expect to hear at least one of his three signature songs, ''Guess Who's in Town?,'' ''Just One of Those Things'' and ''Romance in the Dark,'' along with something by one of the two Dukes (Ellington and Vernon). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:45 and 10:45. Cover: $95.  HOLDEN    Jazz    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.    STEVEN BERNSTEIN'S MILLENNIAL TERRITORY ORCHESTRA, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. The trumpeter Steven Bernstein leads his nine-piece mini-big band through Midwestern and Southwestern music of the 1930's with a revisionist, excitable cast of mind. Sets are tonight at 8 and 10; admission is $10.  BEN RATLIFF    * SASHA DOBSON/CHRIS BYARS OCTET, Fat Cat, 75 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 675-7369. The young singer Sasha Dobson performed a lot with the saxophonist Chris Byars at the old jazz club Smalls, whose owner changed locations and called his new place the Fat Cat. With the recent launching of Small Records and her own release on the label, ''The Darkling Thrush,'' Ms. Dobson returns to her old audience in a new setting. She's a canny improviser with classic Ella-and-Sarah tastes and good pitch; Mr. Byars's arrangements of standards fit her handsomely. Sets are tonight and tomorrow night at 10; cover charge is $10.  RATLIFF    LOU DONALDSON QUARTET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-4037. The saxophonist Lou Donaldson reminds you of the earthiness inside jazz. He is also a wild, funny character who always plays better than you expect on an average night. Sets through Sunday night are at 9 and 11, with a 12:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30.  RATLIFF    STAN GETZ BIRTHDAY TRIBUTE, Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, Midtown, (212) 582-2121. The ubiquitous pianist Bill Charlap, along with the singer Claudia Acuña and the Brazilian jazz band Trio da Paz, play alongside the tenor saxophonist Harry Allen in honor of Getz's New York-to-Rio recorded legacy. Sets tonight and tomorrow at 8, 10, and 11:30, with sets at 8:45 and 10:30 on Sunday; cover charge is $32.50; minimum, $10.  RATLIFF    RUSSELL GUNN AND ETHNOMUSICOLOGY, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Russell Gunn, from St. Louis, is a young hard-core jazz trumpeter who has worked behind R & B stars; logically, he seems to want his work to build a sensible bridge between the jazz and neo-soul audiences. He has a separate, mainstream jazz band, but with Ethnomusicology, he wants to relax you with soul ballads, then to challenge you with crunching dissonance and hard funk. Sets through Sunday night are at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night; cover charge is $25 and $20 on Sunday.  RATLIFF    * COLEMAN HAWKINS CELEBRATION WITH ERIC ALEXANDER AND GEORGE COLEMAN, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Broadway at 60th Street, Manhattan, (212) 258-9595. This is the centennial of the great Coleman Hawkins's birth, and the tribute concerts have been going strong; this one might be particularly good because it's essentially a working group, with Harold Mabern on piano, rather than an ad-hoc confection. The young tenor saxophonist Eric Alexander is probably more indebted to 50's- and 60's-era models like John Coltrane and George Coleman, who appears alongside him in this band. But he and his muse will surely sound good playing ''Body and Soul'' and other Hawkinsiana. Sets through Sunday night are at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night; cover charge is $30; $10 at the tables, $5 at the bar.  RATLIFF    * MARK HELIAS'S OPEN LOOSE, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319. The bassist Mark Helias has been a reliable part of a lot of groups around New York for the last few decades, but his own trio is the best setting in which to hear him, as it engages his compositional sense as well as his convincing bounce. With the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby and the drummer Tom Rainey, he steams through winding themes and great ostinato grooves. Tonight at 8:30; cover charge is $10.  RATLIFF    VICTOR LEWIS GROUP, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-3626. Victor Lewis is a marvelous drummer, known in the 80's for associations with Stan Getz and Bobby Watson and in the 90's for freelancing and playing with his own band. This one includes the saxophonist Seamus Blake and the trumpeter Terrell Stafford. Sets are tonight and tomorrow night at 8, 10 and midnight; cover charge is $20; $10 minimum.  RATLIFF    * BRIAN LYNCH AND SPHERES OF INFLUENCE, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. With a recent Doris Duke Foundation grant, Mr. Lynch wrote new music for his band Spheres of Influence, expanding the group in the process; it's now a nonet, with some of the most exciting musicians in the new Latin-jazz scene including the saxophonist Miguel Zenon, the pianist Luis Perdomo and the percussionist Pedro Martinez. Tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; admission is $15 per set.  RATLIFF    HOUSTON PERSON QUARTET, Lenox Lounge, 288 Lenox Avenue near 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 427-0253. The saxophonist Houston Person's background is in the 1950's, when a good deal of jazz was completely submerged in rhythm-and-blues, and he is one of the few mainstream jazz performers today who can routinely find access to the deep language of pleasure from that time. (Many of the others became session musicians, going deeper into the studiousness of jazz or into the meat and potatoes of rock 'n' roll, or they disappeared.) Mr. Person has an elastic, sequential solo-building style that links him to Sonny Rollins, and a fat, breathy tone that links him to Ben Webster. Enjoy him. Sets are tonight and tomorrow night at 9, 10:30 and midnight; cover charge is $20, and there is a one drink minimum.  RATLIFF    TOOTS THIELEMANS-KENNY WERNER-OSCAR CASTRO-NEVES-AIRTO MOREIRA, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592. A Belgian-American-Brazilian configuration of jazz musicians with big ears and great songbook knowledge on, respectively, harmonica, piano, guitar and percussion. Sets through Sunday night are at 8 and 10:30; cover charge is $35 at the tables with a $15 minimum, and $20 at the bar with a one-drink minimum.  RATLIFF    STEVE TURRE QUINTET, Smoke, 2751 Broadway at 106th Street, Manhattan, (212) 864-6662. The trombonist Steve Turre has knocked around jazz, Latin music, funk and all kinds of professional situations, including a long-standing place in the ''Saturday Night Live'' band; he was also an associate of the great, eccentric saxophonist Rahsaan Roland Kirk and pays tribute to him on a new record, ''The Spirits Up Above'' (Highnote). Sets tonight and tomorrow at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $20; there is a $10 minimum.  RATLIFF    Classical    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera and classical music events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. * denotes a highly recommended event. Full reviews of recent classical music and opera performances: nytimes.com/music.    Opera    'AIDA' The Metropolitan Opera can excel on occasion in making a spectacle of itself; at least the spectacle is warranted in Verdi's ''Aida,'' which was originally conceived as grand opera. Lots of different singers have wafted through this revival this season; this afternoon's cast includes Norma Fantini as Aida, Irina Mishura as Amneris and Ambrogio Maestri, who made his company debut this month, as Amonasro. When he's on, Franco Farina is a ringing Radames, and the excellent Marcello Viotti conducts. Add a few armies of dancers and horses and you could have a fine old time. Tomorrow afternoon at 1:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $145 to $315; returns may be available at the box office.  ANNE MIDGETTE    'LA BOHÉME' The ascent of the golden-voiced Russian soprano Anna Netrebko has been so rapid that no doubt many local opera fans are yet to hear her live. This weekend provides another opportunity as she sings Musetta at the Met in Franco Zeffirelli's outsize production of this Puccini favorite. At her side will be Ruth Ann Swenson as Mimi. It's a heftier and more dramatic role for Ms. Swenson, who is better known for her beautifully nimble coloratura soprano, but she held her own last month at the first performance. Elsewhere in the cast, Peter Mattei sings an impressive Marcello, with rich, deep colors in his baritone. Frank Lopardo has replaced Marcelo Alvarez as Rodolfo. Daniel Oren conducts. Tomorrow night at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $40 to $215.  JEREMY EICHLER    'TANNHÄUSER' At 50, the German dramatic tenor Peter Seiffert, who has a major career in Europe, has finally made his Metropolitan Opera debut in the daunting title role of Wagner's ''Tannhäuser,'' a revival of Otto Schenk's handsomely realistic 1977 production. For Met fans it was worth the wait. Mr. Seiffert has all the power and stamina you could want from a Wagnerian tenor, and, rarer, true tenorial colorings and impressive vocal agility. Though he has a barrel-chested physique, he gives a charismatic, physically nimble and sympathetic portrayal of the medieval knight and song minstrel torn between the erotic pleasures of Venus and the idealized love of Elisabeth. As Elisabeth the soprano Deborah Voigt, who has shed weight and looked splendid, sings with gleaming sound and effortless power. Thomas Hampson brings the elegance of the fine German lieder singer he is to his distinguished and vocally robust portrayal of Wolfram. The mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung is a striking and vocally impassioned Venus, though she is still finding her way into the role technically. Mark Elder conducts a lithe and vividly colored performance. Tonight at 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $35 to $315.  ANTHONY TOMMASINI    Classical Music    FERRARA ENSEMBLE The valuable Music Before 1800 series is presenting this Swiss vocal and instrumental ensemble in ''Très Riche Heures: Gothic Music for the Valois Dukes,'' a program of French courtly love songs from the 14th and 15th centuries. The group, directed by Crawford Young (who also plays the lute in the ensemble), is an outgrowth of a 1984 recording project at the Schola Cantorum Basiliensis, where it is now an ensemble in residence. Its program includes ballades, rondeaus and instrumental pieces by Machaut, Caserta, Paullet, Foliot, Vaillant and Grenon. Sunday at 4 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Manhattan, (212) 666-9266. Tickets: $25 to $40; $20 to $35 for students and 62+.  ALLAN KOZINN    ANDRÉ WATTS This pianist has been an uneven player in recent years, but a chamber music concert at the Metropolitan Museum last week found him in fine shape. For his recital on Sunday, Mr. Watts is performing a varied program that includes a group of Scarlatti Sonatas, Haydn's Sonata No. 58 in C, Schubert's Klavierstücke (D. 946), Debussy's ''Estampes,'' Lizst's ''Hungarian Rhapsody'' No. 13, as well as selections from ''Musica Ricercata,'' a 1951 suite by the great contemporary Hungarian composer Gyorgy Ligeti. Sunday at 3, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Tickets: $12 to $54.  KOZINN    Art    A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show. Full reviews of recent museum and gallery shows: nytimes.com/art.    Museums    * 'THE ART OF ROMARE BEARDEN,' Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Jan. 9. It's a pity only that this retrospective is so big. Art like Bearden's -- mostly small, intense and intricate -- deserves close scrutiny. His genius, aside from his poetic knack for piecing scraps of photographs and other tiny tidbits together, was to see collage as an inherent social metaphor: that its essence was to turn nothings into something, making disparate elements cohere, a positivist enterprise. His collages celebrated black culture and personal history, combined African masks with ancient Greek art, Matisse with patchwork quilts. ''There are roads out of secret places within us along which we all must move as we go to touch others,'' Bearden said. And that's exactly where he takes us. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+.  MICHAEL KIMMELMAN    'ASIAN GAMES: THE ART OF CONTEST,' Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 327-9211, through Jan. 16. What's your game? Chess, go, pachisi, polo? These and many other recreational pursuits are saluted in a jampacked but beguiling show that pegs Asia as the continent of origin for more than a few of the sophisticated games we play today. On view are 200 games and game-related objects covering 2,000 years. They involve games of chance; memory and matching; strategy and physical skill. Elaborate boards for dice-propelled contests like pachisi, backgammon and snakes and ladders; different varieties of dice; intricately carved chessmen; lively examples of playing cards, and intriguing paraphernalia for outdoor sports like polo, are all part of this sumptuous display, enhanced by paintings, prints, sculptures and decorative accessories. A playground for the eye, even a non-gamesman's. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+.  GRACE GLUECK    * 'THE AZTEC EMPIRE,' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Feb. 13. When a big survey of Aztec art opened in London in 2002, everybody flipped out. It was one of the hottest ancient-art events since Tutankhamen. Now an expanded version of the London show is at the Guggenheim, and it's a stunner. Objects from pre-Aztec Mexico set the stage, but it is material from the bloody-minded, deity-besotted Aztec culture that fills the museum's darkened ramps. Set on jutting platforms and dark recesses are a skull-headed earth goddess in a skirt of writhing snakes, a warrior metamorphizing into a bird and a god of spring and fertility shedding his skin. The show may be a little too heavy on theater and too light on information, but it's totally mesmerizing. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $18; $15, students and 65+.  HOLLAND COTTER    * 'CHINA: DAWN OF A GOLDEN AGE, 200-750 A.D,' the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 23. Almost all of the 350 objects in this splendid and rigorous exhibition are straight from China; a few were unearthed as recently as last year. But the show is far less about trophy archaeology than about history or about how archaeology is shaped into history. There are a few monumental sculptures; most of the objects, of gold, silver, bronze, lacquer and ceramic, are small, but absolutely riveting. And the guiding theme -- that China, far from being a pure, monolithic source from which peripheral cultures drew, took from the larger world at least as much as it gave -- has everything to say to our own multicultural time. It's a show that asks you to do some work, but there is so much of interest to look at that no one, even the casual drive-by viewer, will feel shortchanged. Hours: Sundays, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7.  COTTER    * 'COMIC GROTESQUE: WIT AND MOCKERY IN GERMAN ART, 1870-1940,' Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, through Feb. 14. The horrors of World War I are usually credited with triggering the dark, often scathing humor that was used to comment on and combat some very unfunny developments in Germany in the first four decades of the century. But the Neue Galerie's splendidly multimedia revisionist show takes a broader view. It identifies paintings by Arnold Böcklin from the 1870's as a point of origin and then sweeps forward in a selective yet encompassing manner, touching on painting, poetry, graphic design and popular entertainment. It shows the influences of the satiric illustrator Thomas Theodor Heine on the mordant anti-Nazi montages of John Heartfield, and places artists like Lionel Feininger and Alfred Kubin in context. It culminates in the films of the great Karl Valentin, the star of stage, screen and cabaret who was Germany's Charlie Chaplin. Hours: Saturdays through Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7.  ROBERTA SMITH    'MANNY FARBER: ABOUT FACE,' AND 'KATHARINA SIEVERDING: CLOSE UP,' P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084; through Jan. 16 and Jan. 23, respectively. P.S. 1's two major fall shows are about identity defined through two different approaches to self-portraiture. Mr. Farber's show is a 40-year retrospective of work by a California artist well known as a film critic, who since the 1970's has been producing large, highly detailed still lifes. The pictures are dense with autobiographical data, from images of movie-house candy bars to handwritten notes-to-self to flowers picked fresh from the garden. The work of Ms. Sieverding of Germany could hardly be a greater visual contrast. Her series of colossal head shots suggesting film advertisements are mostly of her own face. The results are both an exercise in self-celebration, and the simultaneous creation and undermining of a personal-is-political icon. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+.  COTTER    'GREAT EXPECTATIONS: JOHN SINGER SARGENT PAINTING CHILDREN,' Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 16. Primarily known for his dashing portraits of high-born ladies sumptuously decked out, Sargent painted other subjects, too, not least among them children. This show, presenting about 40 works, has large ambitions. A major one is exploring how Sargent's likenesses tied in with the changing notions of childhood at the end of the 19th century, when children began to be regarded as distinctive personalities in their own right. For the most part here, he seems to see his young subjects that way, rather than as the syrupy stereotypes portrayed by his Victorian and 18th-century predecessors. Said to be the first exhibition to bring together Sargent's influential portraits of children, the show, with its catalog, is a refreshing new take on this bravura brushmeister. Hours: Wednesdays to Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of every month). Admission: $8; students and 65+, $4.  GLUECK    MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: PERMANENT COLLECTION, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400. There are problems with the new Museum of Modern Art, starting with its egregious $20 ticket price. The fairly inchoate assemblage of paintings, sculptures, drawings, photographs and films from the last 30 years in the suite of double-height galleries for contemporary art on the second floor spells trouble, too. The Modern clearly still has to deal with the conflict between its historic authority when it comes to art of the first 60 or so years of the 20th century and the indeterminacy of its taste in recent art. But the building is exquisite, a great gift to the city, and you would have to be either comatose or completely immune to the pleasures of modernism not to be moved by its fifth floor, the start of the rooms for painting and sculpture. Here is the familiar, early story of modernism that the Modern virtually invented under its founding director and genius, Alfred H. Barr Jr., now retold in an installation that is about as ravishing as any sequence of galleries in any new museum in recent memory. The mobs will inevitably congregate on that floor, so a good alternative for visitors is to explore the museum within the museum: the suites of galleries for prints, drawings, photographs and design -- mostly intimate places to peruse some of the greatest of all works of modern art. Prints provide a sublime survey of the medium up to the present. Drawings, packed in like sardines, concentrate on the period 1880 to 1945, with installations in coming months to focus on more recent eras. Photographs, skewed to the present, demonstrate how diverse that medium has become. And design is divided between two spaces, one a dense hodgepodge of objects, new and old, including chairs, pitchers, posters and automobiles, the other a mix of architectural models and drawings. With its stress on everyday objects, the design collection represents the core philosophy of the museum as it evolved in its early days: to extend modernism into the lives of ordinary people. As a 1949 museum Bulletin put it, ''Modern art is an intrinsic part of modern living.'' The new Modern, adopted already into the hearts and minds of New Yorkers, is itself the best proof how true that is. Hours: Saturdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; closed Tuesdays. Admission: $20; $16 for 65+; $12 for students. Free on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m.  KIMMELMAN    'ISAMU NOGUCHI: MASTER SCULPTOR,' Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Aveune, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Jan. 16. In this well-planned chronicle of Noguchi's lifelong engagement with three-dimensional form, the highlight is a stunning gallery devoted to his anthropomorphic sculptures from the 1940's -- bony-looking vertical articulations that are surreal abstractions of body traits and attitudes. But the show highlights other important areas of his achievement, not least of them the products of his early days in Paris (1927-28) where he turned out a wonderful series of abstract drawings that integrate biomorphic and geometric shapes with line, signaling his embrace of modernist art. The show does not neglect his monumental pieces, which are displayed in the last gallery. Hours and admission: see above.  GLUECK    * 'PERSONAL AFFECTS: POWER AND POETICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOUTH AFRICAN ART,' Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700) and St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 111th Street, through Jan. 3 and Dec. 5, respectively. This two-part exhibition traces what its curators call a ''post-identity'' development in South African art since the end of apartheid, with issues of class, race and gender subsumed under other personal or abstract concerns. For the occasion, the museum commissioned new pieces from 17 artists, some specifically for the cathedral. The installation there is more than just effective. It's the strongest group show of new art anywhere in the city so far this season. But certain artists are seen to better advantage in the smaller-scale spaces of the Museum of African art itself. All in all, the show's two halves are forcefully complementary. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 5 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students and 65+.  COTTER    * 'PRINCELY SPLENDOR: THE DRESDEN COURT, 1580-1620,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 30. A densely baubled selection of some of the tools, armor, sculpture and bejeweled gewgaws that the princes of Dresden accumulated in the late 16th and early 17th centuries. Ignore the hackneyed and pompous exhibition title and consider this a constructive reminder of the artistic roots of wonderment. Besides ivory handled hammers, a 14-piece pocketknife, silk doublets trimmed in silver and gold, a brass horn and several automatons, which move about on hidden mechanized wheels, there is a portable hunting and writing desk. It is neatly stocked with gardening tools, writing and painting implements, cupping glasses, an oil cruet, soap boxes, scales, strainers, funnels, vintner's tools, barber's instruments, farrier's tools, locksmith tools -- in sum, the world, as a mirror of divine reason, a cabinet of wonders, for princes who had everything. Hours and admission: see above.  KIMMELMAN    'QUEENS INTERNATIONAL,' Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700, through Feb. 6. The 40 artists here are all residents of the city's most cosmopolitan borough, though nearly a third were born outside the United States. In line with current curatorial trends, overt displays of ethnicity are played down and a certain blandness prevails. But there is some interesting work, including paintings by the Japanese-American Hideo Date, now 97 and a Queens citizen for more than half a century. His two soft-grained figurative paintings from the 1930's and 40's emanate from a distant stylistic world, one that looks fine right now. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+.  COTTER    'TOTEMS TO TURQUOISE: NATIVE NORTH AMERICAN JEWELRY ARTS OF THE NORTHWEST AND SOUTHWEST,' American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, through July 10. Think of cave murals and Renaissance altarpieces used to contextualize examples of modern and contemporary painting and you've got the equivalent of this exhibition, a mixed bag of old and new, quality and special pleading. Here examples of jewelry and other small objects that date back to prehistoric times lend credence to late 20th and 21st century works that are sometimes little more than glitzy knockoffs. Enough recent efforts stand out to make the show a valuable essay on the very notion of traditions, how they are formed, perpetuated, renewed, exploited or exhausted. But claiming to follow the beliefs or crafts of one's ancestors does not guarantee a special purchase on spirituality. All art is essentially a faith-based initiative. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $13; children, $7.50; students and 62+, $10.  SMITH    Galleries: Uptown    BRYAN HUNT: 'AIRSHIPS,' Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400, through Dec. 11. Mr. Hunt became known in the mid 70's for beautiful sculptures in the form of miniature dirigibles made with balsa wood interior framing and paper skins covered with metal leaf or paint. Eight of these works, ranging in length from 40 to 64 inches, are on view here. Attached to the wall at one end, they hover mysteriously overhead.  KEN JOHNSON    ALFRED LESLIE: 'EXPRESSING THE ZEITGEIST,' Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, (212) 987-4997, through Dec. 22. Although primarily thought of today as a realist painter, Leslie started out as a second-generation Abstract Expressionist, a mover and shaker of the downtown world. This presentation of his vibrant early work from 1951 to 1962 ranges from tiny collages to large canvases, whose colors, chosen from a broad palette, were energetically laid on with heavy, loaded brushstrokes exuberantly accompanied by drips and spatter. They characteristically carry a pair or two of painted bars that punctuate the highly textured, often collaged surfaces like exclamation points.  GLUECK    * 'NEUE SACHLICHKEIT: NEW OBJECTIVITY IN WEIMAR GERMANY,' Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through Dec. 18. Heralded by the Expressionist Ludwig Meidner as a ''fanatical, fervent naturalism,'' the ostensibly realist style known as Neue Sachlichkeit was all that and more, as this uneven 80-work show vigorously suggests. It features the majestically factual photographs of August Sander, Karl Blossfeldt and Albert Renger-Patzsch, and works based on photographs by Georg Scholz, Eddy Smith and George Grosz that bring out reality's grotesque side. Carl Grossberg's pared-down, jewel-colored portrayals of German factories and villages evoke American Precisionism.  SMITH    A. R. PENCK: 'CONSTRUCTIONS,' Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623, through Dec. 18. Mr. Penck's primitivistic paintings featuring stick figures and pictographic signs became internationally visible during the triumph of German Neo-Expressionism in the 1980's. This exhibition features something different: compact, slapdash constructions mostly from the early 70's made of found objects and materials like bottles, cardboard boxes, wire, fabric, tape and newspaper. Displayed on a single table that almost fills the gallery, they create a vaguely comical theater of the absurd.  JOHNSON    * 'PICASSO-BECKMANN/BECKMANN-PICASSO,' Richard L. Feigen, 34 East 69th Street, (212) 628-0700, through Jan. 31. This wonderfully illuminating exhibition brings together two great 20th-century artists who are not ordinarily closely associated. It includes significant as well as interesting minor works by both. Picasso's colorful, thickly painted late-30's picture of a bull goring a horse is worth a visit all by itself, and so is Beckmann's ''Soldier's Dream'' from 1942, a darkly comical allegory of lust and death with bird-man and bird-woman lovers.  JOHNSON    'SO FAR SO CLOSE: CONTEMPORARY ART FROM GUADALAJARA,' The Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 277-8343, through Jan. 21. This five-artist exhibition is intended to show that Mexico City is not the only scene of serious contemporary art in Mexico. It includes a Delftware motorcycle helmet by Agustin Solórzano; gold-glazed ceramic tacos by Luis Miguel Suro; an absorbing video showing puzzling crowd behavior by Gonzalo Lebrija; Fernando Palomar's mural-scale silhouette of a Dutch landscape; and Rem Koolhass's book ''S,M,L,XL'' cut up into four different size pieces by José Dávila.  JOHNSON    Galleries: 57th Street    WAYNE THIEBAUD, 'JUST DESSERTS,' Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331, through Dec. 18. No one did more to reanimate the tired old genre of still life painting in the last half century than did Mr. Thiebaud with his paintings of industrially regimented food products. His prints, sampled here in a 50-year retrospective, are less exciting than his paintings. Most are in black and white and on the small side. But they still convey the artist's wry vision of modern consumerism with forthright graphic efficiency, and the full-color prints of cans of paint, a row of lipsticks and a white rabbit are lovely.  JOHNSON    Galleries: SoHo    'THE ART OF READING,' Poets House, 72 Spring Street, (212) 431-7920, through Dec. 4 . This appropriately quiet presentation of 38 small paintings, drawings, prints and photographs of people reading includes Paul Cadmus's portrait of Glenway Wescott; David Hockney's sweet colored-pencil drawing of a young man reclining on a sofa; photographs of William S. Burroughs by Allen Ginsberg; and King Babar (the elephant) reading his newspaper at the beach in a watercolor by Laurent DeBrunhoff.  JOHNSON    CARMEN CICERO, June Kelly, 591 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 226-1660, through Dec. 14. Mr. Cicero's cartoonish, easel-size narrative paintings combine humor, gothic mystery and Magritte-style surrealism. In some, men in trenchcoats and fedoras walk through landscapes of dreamlike desolation or drive old cars on nocturnal country roads; in others emblematic images like a knight's helmet or a locomotive hover like mystical signs. Mr. Cicero is not an Outsider -- he has been exhibiting his art since the early 50's and earned a M.F.A. degree in 1991 -- but his work has the hair-raising feeling of a self-taught visionary's.  JOHNSON    GEORGE GROSZ: 'NEW YORK DRAWINGS,' Nolan/Eckman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-6190, through Dec. 4. This fascinating exhibition presents a series of ink drawings made to illustrate a 1941 collection of writings by the journalist Ben Hecht called ''1001 Afternoons in New York.'' Grosz, who moved to New York in 1933, may have done his best work during his Weimar years, but this show of never-before-exhibited drawings shows he did not leave behind his extraordinarily prehensile draftsmanship or his incisively satiric imagination.  JOHNSON    * 'RICHARD TUTTLE: IT'S A ROOM FOR 3 PEOPLE,' the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166, through Feb. 26. ''Villages'' is what Mr. Tuttle calls the five separate installations in this knotty but sparkling show of recent work. Each consists of a sculpture and two series of small drawings or paintings; no distinction is made. Each series is internally linked by a visual motif or color. The results are enchanting. They disarm aesthetic pretensions like Genius, Beauty and Greatness. They offer an adult way of seeing art and the world with a child's fresh eye. And the world according to Tuttle is a singularly rich one, minutely detailed, culturally broad, exotic and familiar, cosmopolitan and home-grown.  COTTER    Galleries: Chelsea    SEONNA HONG: 'ANIMUS,' Oliver Kamm/5BE, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-0979, through Dec. 4. This Los Angeles-based artist won an Emmy this year for her animation work on an episode of the television cartoon series ''My Life as a Teenage Robot.'' Her first solo gallery exhibition in New York presents retro-style illustrations beautifully painted on wood panels for a yet-to-be-published picture book about a little girl and a vicious black dog.  JOHNSON    RICHARD KERN/LILY VAN DER STOKKER, Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 675-7772, through Dec. 11. These separate solo shows could be presented under the single title ''Innocence and Experience.'' Mr. Kern's voyeuristic, snapshot-style pictures of women -- staged using attractive models -- are uncommonly visceral instances of the so-called male gaze. Ms. van der Stokker's aggressively charming pastel-colored wall paintings of abstract blobs, cartoon flowers, plaid patterns and quirky texts project a childlike sweetness, wholesome family values and mischievous ironies.  JOHNSON    CILDO MEIRELES: 'DESCALA' AND 'STRICTU,' Galerie Lelong, 528 West 26th Street, (212) 315-0470, through Dec. 4. Concerned with changing the spectator's role from passive to active, Mr. Meireles, a Brazilian environmental artist, offers a heavy-breathing account of how spaces can be used to control mind and body. On a wooden interrogation table in a dark room is a statement condemning societal authoritarianism. The viewer is invited to don handcuffs attached to a ball and chain while viewing the second work: flat ladders and runged poles line the walls of a smaller gallery, creating a handsome compositional surround, Mondrianlike in its reductive effect.  GLUECK    BEATRIZ MILHAZES: 'SUMMERTIME,' James Cohan, 533 West 26th Street, (212) 714-9500, through Dec. 4. This Rio de Janeiro-based painter continues to produce large abstractions that teeter on the divide between the expressive and the decorative. Ms. Milhaze layers radiating blossoms, target patterns, stripes, hearts, butterflies and peace signs onto gridded patchworks of rich color. With their sensuously textured, gold leaf-accented surfaces and neo-hippie exuberance the paintings promise but don't quite deliver something really over the top.  JOHNSON    Other Galleries    * 'AN AMERICAN ODYSSEY: 1945-1980 [DEBATING MODERNISM],' Queensborough Community College Art Gallery, 222-05 56th Avenue, Bayside, (718) 631-6396, through Jan. 13. Recently reopened after a two-year renovation, this gallery is being promoted as a showplace, and justly so: it looks spiffy and its opening show is an ambitous one that rethinks canonical accounts of American modernism. Gold-standard artists like Pollock are joined by less successful contemporaries, and Photo Realism, a movement until recently out of favor, is reconsidered. Is the show cohesive? No, but it's stimulating and fun, with some terrific underknown works by familiar artists.  COTTER    IAN HAMILTON FINLAY, UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, near 52nd Street, (212) 713-2885, through Dec. 3. Mr. Finlay, a Scottish poet, artist, gardener and rebel, born in 1925, aches for the past and feels its impact on the present. His graphic works are inspired by the French Revolution, classical art and literature, boats, World War II and his renowned garden. An expert typographer, he often fashions images from words or combinations of letters alone, placing them in punchy arrangements. Best are his images of ships, which occasionally take wry turns. Type fanciers and concrete poetry buffs will have a picnic; others may want to take along a cryptograph to fathom his buried meanings.  GLUECK    'ELECTRIFYING ART: ATSUKO TANAKA, 1954-1968,' Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 11. In the late 1950's and early 1960's, Ms. Tanaka was a member of the avant-garde Japanese art group called Gutai, and the Grey Gallery survey covers the years of that association. It's a visually low-key show, but one with lots of ideas from an artist who was doing proto-Conceptualist and proto-Minimalist work and very early versions of sound and performance art. Spend time with the short films in the galleries; they bring everything else to life. COTTER    'JAMAICA FLUX: WORKSPACES AND WINDOWS,' Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning, 161-04 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, (718) 658-7400, through Jan. 8. Although some of the work in this ambitious show is in the gallery, much is embedded in the surrounding environment, a major shopping strip. A local branch of North Fork Bank yields sculptures on the themes of wealth and illusions. Street posters adapt corporate marketing strategies to ecourage the use of libraries. The collective called Center for Urban Pedagogy planted models for urban architecture among footwear displays in Sneaker Mart Plus, and the artist Liselot van der Heijden's places a pointedly edited version of George W. Bush's 2004 State of the Union address in a shop among tapes of speeches by Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  COTTER    ARCHIE RAND: 'THE 19 DIASPORA PAINTINGS,' Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205, through Jan. 12. The mercurial Mr. Rand has created a series of canvases representing the Biblical history of Israel using imagery copied in a loose, colorful style from various sorts of adventure comic books. Each is captioned by Hebrew words of a traditional prayer. The paintings are unconvincing visually, but the effort to wed traditional religion and Postmodernist art is interesting.  JOHNSON    SITE, Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767, through Dec. 4. A cool new addition to Madison Square Park is the ''Shake Shack,'' a fast-food kiosk designed by the architecture firm Sculpture in the Environment (SITE) that was founded in 1970 by James Wines. It is partly a Postmodern hot dog stand, partly green architecture with its vegetation-covered roof and partly a way to generate revenue for the park. The small show of models and drawings at Senior & Shopmaker gives some background on Mr. Wines's inventive and admirable effort to integrate form, function and environment.  JOHNSON

Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

abstract: Number of United States citizens weigh emigrating in wake of Pres Bush's re-election; new intellectual and political refugees contrast with libertarians, retirees and other so-called 'economic refugees' who moved abroad in past decades seeking lower cost of living and reduced taxes; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: FOR most John Kerry supporters, it went no further than an idle election night threat.
